DOC.HEAD: Report: Coast Guardsmen Helped Cocaine Smugglers in Florida
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Coast Guard saying it ended alleged conspiracy back in 1988.
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guardsmen in the Florida Keys have worked for cocaine smugglers, selling them agents' codes and disabling patrol boats, according to a report broadcast Sunday. When they raided smugglers' homes, federal authorities found records of secret radio frequencies, patrol schedules and codes used in radio transmissions for every law enforcement agency in the Florida Keys, NBC's ``Expose'' show reported. The report made no mention of when the alleged corruption occurred. However, Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Karonis, spokesman for the Coast Guard's southeastern district based in Miami, told The Associated Press that the Coast Guard had put an end to the alleged conspiracy back in 1988. ``The Coast Guard people involved were brought to justice and are in jail right now. The system works and they're paying for it,'' Karonis said after viewing the broadcast Sunday. The NBC report cited unidentified federal authorities and Tom Cash, an official with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration in Miami. Federal authorities probing the relationship between smugglers and Coast Guardsmen named the case ``Operation Tempest.'' At least 15 guardsmen assigned to the Islamorada station worked for or with the smugglers they were assigned to catch, NBC reported. Admiral Paul Yost, Coast Guard commandant, said he was unaware of any federal investigation of cocaine involvement in the Coast Guard, NBC said. ``We've got almost no drug corruption _ one or two isolated cases,'' Yost said. Four Islamorada guardsmen who crewed a high-speed boat intended to intercept smugglers are in jail for taking cocaine from the smugglers, NBC said. Art Sola, commander of the crew that allegedly stole cocaine from smugglers for themselves, told NBC he and his fellow guardsmen decided one afternoon to steal a kilogram of cocaine from a load they found floating in the Atlantic Ocean 15 miles offshore. The cocaine was worth as much as $16,000 _ about the same as the guardsmen's salary. ``It's easy. It's very easy. It's a lifestyle down there. Everybody knows somebody who's involved in drugs or smuggling. It's very easy to get hooked on,'' Sola said in an interview in jail. Another guardsman, Bobby Gosnell, got caught up in drug smuggling but wound up murdered, NBC said. After he left the Coast Guard, Gosnell bought a $500,000 home complete with an airstrip, the station said. Gosnell was shot in the chest in a dispute over whether he should cooperate with the federal investigation, NBC said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Stormie Jones Heading Back to Pittsburgh After Liver Shows Rejection
DOC.TEXT: Doctors suspect Stormie Jones, the world's first recipient of a heart-liver transplant, is rejecting her second transplanted liver, and plan to examine her at a Pittsburgh hospital, a spokeswoman said late Saturday. Stormie, 12, was scheduled to leave her home in this Fort Worth suburb Sunday for Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh after her liver enzyme count shot to dangerously high levels, said family friend Theresa Millikan. Hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon said in a statement that doctors suspect Stormie may be rejecting the second transplanted liver she received Feb. 20. Stormie's condition has been constantly monitored since she became the world's first heart-liver transplant patient on Feb. 14, 1984. The youngster's first transplanted liver was damaged by hepatitus caused by an unknown virus. Doctors thought she was progressing well after the second transplant, but increasing evidence of rejection became clear in recent tests. Stormie's liver enzyme count, a figure used to measure rejection, was between 550 and 600 on Friday morning, an extremely high level. By Saturday, it had shot up to 1,300, Mrs. Millikan said. Stormie rested Saturday night at her home. ``Stormie is real nervous,'' Mrs. Millikan said. ``She doesn't want to be stuck with any more needles. She told us she's had enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Pleasure Boat Strikes Bridge Pillar on Rain-Swollen Missouri River
DOC.TEXT: A pleasure boat struck the underpinning of a highway bridge Saturday night on the rain-swollen Missouri River, slightly injuring 22 passengers sent sprawling across decks by the impact. The double-decked boat, the Spirit of St. Charles, struck a bridge pillar as it tried to turn downstream, said Ray Kemp, public affairs officer for the St. Charles County ambulance service. ``There was a lot of screaming because the impact was pretty strong,'' he said. ``A little girl fell down some stairs, but she wasn't seriously hurt.'' The injured were treated at St. Joseph Health Center, said Barbara Wussler, the center's community relations director. They were treated for minor injuries, she said. The boat, carrying 217 passengers, returned to a shore of the river, which crested Friday night at St. Charles 10 feet over its 25-foot flood stage. The extent of damage to the boat was not immediately determined. St. Charles is about 20 miles west of St. Louis.

DOC.HEAD: Trinity, Red Rivers Continue Carrying Flood Waters To Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th, `The Red ...' to UPDATE with Hot Springs, Ark., flooding. Pick up 7th graf, `About 1,000 ...' With AM-Flood-Evacuees, Bjt
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HT4,3
DOC.TEXT: Flood-swollen rivers in Texas and Louisiana rushed across thousands of acres of normally dry land to the Gulf of Mexico on Saturday, and President Bush made a close-up survey of the destruction. Some rain was forecast for parts of Texas, including the southeast where the Trinity River is in record flood because of storms weeks ago in northern Texas. Flooding and stormy weather have killed 13 people in Texas, two in Illinois and one in Oklahoma since April 15, and one person was missing in Missouri. Thousands of people have been evacuated at various times in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana. Estimates still are being compiled on the amounts of damage to crops and property but it is expected to exceed hundreds of millions of dollars. Scattered flooding also was reported Saturday in parts of Iowa and Illinois and residents cleaned up after floods in Indiana and Mississippi. ``In Louisiana we have one commodity ready to harvest, winter wheat. That's gone in the flooded areas,'' said Larry Michaud, of the state Agriculture Department. ``There will be extensive damage to the cotton in the area.'' The Red River was returning to its banks in Arkansas, but preliminary damage estimates were rising. Heavy rain Saturday caused flooding in Hot Springs, where water up to 4 feet deep rushed along a downtown street, police said. Store workers used sandbags to hold back the rain. About 1,000 cattle, valued at $700,000, drowned in Arkansas' Little River County, said Jim Barnes, executive director in the county for the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation service. Damage to homes and other buildings was estimated at $1.5 million. Bush, on a weekend visit to Texas, briefly visited the Livingston Dam on the Trinity River in southeastern Texas, and flew over flooded areas downstream on the river northeast of Houston. ``This is remarkable,'' Bush told Polk County Judge Wayne Baker. ``I remember it was fairly dry here not too many years ago.'' The Federal Emergency Management Agency announced Saturday that three more Texas counties were declared disaster areas due to spring flooding, bringing the total to 41 of the state's 254 counties. Flood crests moving down the Trinity had forced managers of the Livingston Dam to release water through the spillways at the rate of 100,800 cubic feet per second or 756,000 gallons a second since Thursday morning. An estimated 7,000 people living in scattered, low-lying subdivisions downstream from the dam were warned a week earlier that they should evacuate. About 100 river miles downstream, at the town of Liberty, the Trinity was already 5 feet over flood stage, said Sandra Sanford, a volunteer at the county's emergency services office. ``If it rains, we may have some more problems,'' she said. ``We're praying we don't get any more rain storms.'' ``They realize that the river's still coming up but some people just don't want to leave,'' she said. In Louisiana, officials said the swollen Red River probably has done most of its damage, but forecasters warned farmers and riverfront businesses along the upper Mississippi River to prepare for high water from storms in the Midwest. The Red was expected to crest at 40 feet, eight above flood stage, Sunday at Alexandria in central Louisiana. But levees and floodgates protect most of area between Alexandria and Avoyelles Parish, where the Red meets the bigger Atchafalaya River, officials said. At least 90,000 acres _ about 140 square miles _ of farmland has been flooded in Louisiana, government officials said. The Army Corps of Engineers had predicted that 350,000 acres of farmland and about an equal amount of forest land would be flooded. However, corps hydrologist Frankie Griggs said those estimates had not been revised to take into account flood crests a foot lower than originally expected. In western Iowa, more than 200 people living along Perry Creek in Sioux City, including 77 from a nursing home, were evacuated early Saturday because of a flash flood, but were able to return home after sunrise. The flood followed as much as 4.5 inches of rain overnight. Southern Illinois braced for more storms and the prospect of flash flooding Saturday, as rivers strained to handle the runoff of almost 7 inches of rain in a little more than a week. Most Missouri rivers were receding, but the Red Cross said Saturday that 208 Kansas City-area homes had been destroyed and 312 suffered major damage.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Kills Seven Palestinians, Wounds 10
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to restore time element to lead, update that gunman not soldier but civilian, add additional details. Pickup 5th graf pvs: The deaths ...
DOC.TEXT: A 20-year-old Israeli armed with a U.S.-made M-16 assault rifle opened fire Sunday on a group of Palestinians waiting to go to work in a town south of Tel Aviv, killing seven and wounding 10, Israel radio said. It was the bloodiest attack by an Israeli against Arabs since the start of the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising. The radio initially said the gunman was apparently an Israeli soldier, but later identified the suspect as a 20-year-old civilian. He escaped in a car belonging to one of the Palestinians, but was taken into custody after contacting police, the radio said. The shooting took place around 6 a.m. Sunday in the town of Rishon Letzion, south of Tel Aviv, in a park where Palestinian laborers from the occupied territories wait to be picked up for jobs in Israel. The deaths raise to 688 the number of Arabs killed by Israelis in the uprising. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence. In April 1989, a lone Israeli wearing army fatigues opened fire with an Uzi submachine gun on a group of Palestinians sitting outside of the old, walled city of Jerusalem, killing one Arab and wounding three others. A man claiming to be from a radical underground group called the Sicarites claimed responsibility for the attack. The group has also claimed responsibility for a number of failed attacks on left-wing Israelis. No arrests were made in the Jerusalem attack.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Telephones Dalton Prejean Shortly Before Execution
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer telephoned Dalton Prejean shortly before his execution and told the killer he had to die to serve society, Prejean's lawyer said. Prejean requested to speak with the governor and Roemer called 90 minutes before Prejean walked to the death house at Louisiana State Penitentiary for his execution early Friday, said the lawyer, John Hall. ``The governor said he thought his execution was the only thing that would serve society and give the proper message back to people who were thinking about killing police officers,'' Hall said. The governor and Prejean talked for about 10 minutes, Hall said. Roemer already had refused to halt Prejean's execution in Louisiana's electric chair. Prejean, 30, became the first murderer to die under the U.S. Supreme Court's 1989 ruling that allowed the death penalty for crimes committed by 16- and 17-year olds. Prejean, who was nearly retarded, was executed for the 1977 murder of state trooper Donald Cleveland, killed during a traffic stop in Lafayette. Prejean was 17 then and had served more than two years in reform school for killing a taxi driver when he was 14. Prejean told Roemer that allowing him live to tell his story to troubled youngsters could help keep them from lives of crime, Hall said. ``Dalton spoke of his remorse and the sorrow and pain he had caused others and said he thought he could reach people, that people could learn from him,'' Hall said. Roemer's spokesman, Rusty Jabour, confirmed the conversation occurred but would not reveal details.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Students Barricade University Campus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Sunday protests, police storming campus. Pickup 9th graf pvs: Students used ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos KWG1,2
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand riot police firing tear gas stormed a university campus Sunday to break up an anti-government rally by 5,000 students and workers. Radical students and workers wielding metal pipes, rocks and firebombs battled police amid a thick fog of tear gas on the campus of Chosun University. Elsewhere in this provincial city, more than 10,000 students rallied at the national Chonnam University, burning a giant U.S. flag and shouting insults at thousands of riot police outside the campus. Police officials said a student from Seoul died in a hospital Saturday of massive head injuries suffered after he jumped off a speeding train on the outskirts of Kwangju. Police said Shin Jang-ho,21, a sophomore at Daeyu Vocational College in Seoul, was among several hundred students who jumped to avoid being arrested at the Kwangju Railway Station. Police checked identities of all students arriving in Kwangju by train, car and bus in an effort to prevent outsiders from joining the protesters. At a downtown hospital where Shin's body was kept, about 500 students, armed with steel pipes and firebombs, stood guard. Police officials expressed concern the death might further radicalize the students. At Chosun University, about 2,500 riot police supported by four armored vans firing hundreds of volleys of tear gas stormed the campus as about 5,000 workers and students were starting an anti-government rally. ``Down with (President) Roh Tae-woo,'' protesters shouted, as they dashed through thick clouds of tear gas to charge the police lines. About 300 protesters barricaded themselved on the roofs of several school buildings, pelting police with rocks and firebombs. About a dozen police officers were injured and evacuated. Some women protesters, overcome by the tear gas, were carried into campus buildings by colleagues. At Chonnam University, about 25,000 students held a rally overnight during which they demanded the ouster of Roh and U.S. troops based in Korea. ``Yankee go home,'' students screamed jabbing their hands in the air. The students planned to hold a mass anti-government rally Sunday in central Kwangju with dissident groups. Police said the rally would be illegal, and they planned to block it. Early Saturday, about 3,500 police supported by armored tear-gas vans surrounded the Chonnam campus and searched all visitors. About 230 students were arrested, police said. But as news of the student's death spread, the riot police withdrew, apparently to avoid provoking protesters. The number of students at the school increased sharply after the police departed. Students used tires, school desks, chairs and broken furniture to erect 10- to 12-foot-high barricades at the university's three gates. More than 500 students armed with 3-foot-long metal pipes stood guard inside each one. ``Our nation has no hope until (President) Roh Tae-woo and the United States are ousted,'' student leader Song Gap-suk told a rally. Song, a fugitive being sought by police for instigating violent protests, said the U.S. military presence in South Korea is a major obstacle to Seoul's unification with communist North Korea. The crowd applauded and cheered wildly. About 43,000 U.S. troops are stationed in South Korea. In downtown Kwangju, several groups of 50 to 100 students hurled rocks and firebombs at riot police in sporadic clashes during the day. Police dispersed them with tear gas. About 7,000 people rioted in the streets of this city on Friday, the 10th anniversary of a pro-democracy revolt that was crushed by the military. At least 200 civilians were killed in the 10-day uprising, the worst in modern Korean history. Friday's protesters attacked police with rocks and firebombs and demanded the ouster of Roh. The anniversary also was marked by protests in more than a dozen other cities, and police said about 5,300 people were arrested. Police said all but 481 of the 4,325 arrested in Seoul had been released. They said 123 people were arrested in Kwangju and that at least were 20 injured. Anti-U.S. and anti-government sentiment is strong in Kwangju, a city of more than 1 million people 156 miles south of Seoul. Many citizens feel the United States stood by and condoned the bloody suppression in 1980. Washington repeatedly has denied the charges. The U.S. cultural center in the city was forced to close last year after it was attacked by radicals 28 times since the early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed in Crash of Marine Corps Helicopter
DOC.TEXT: A Marine Corps helicopter crashed during a training flight Saturday, killing one of six crew members, officials said. The CH-53D helicopter had mechanical difficulty and crashed about 15 miles south of Salton Sea, said a statement from the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing headquarters at El Toro Marine Corps Air Station. The conditions of the five survivors were not immediately available. The names of all six crew members were withheld pending notification of relatives. The cause of the crash was under investigation. The CH-53D, or Delta model, is known as the ``Sea Stallion.'' It is powered by two engines. In 1985, 17 Marines were lost at sea and presumed dead when a Sea Stallion crashed off the southern coast of Japan. In 1987, four Marines survived a fiery crash of a Sea Stallion in the Arizona desert. The helicopter was based at the Tustin station in Orange County and was attached to Marine Heavy Helicopter Squadron 363. Salton City is about 55 miles southeast of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Vote After Violent Campaign Polarized Country
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with polls opening, other details. Pickup 2nd graf pvs: The elections ...; SUBS 7th graf, Ballot counting ..., to clarify that preliminary results expected Monday, pickup 8th graf pvs: State-run television...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XBUC5
DOC.TEXT: Romanians went to the polls Sunday in their first free elections in more than 50 years after a violent campaign that polarized and politicized this former hard-line Communist country. Some 12,400 polling places opened throughout the country at 6 a.m., as voters turned out to choose a president and members of a 506-seat, two-chamber parliament. ``These elections are a step toward democracy,'' said Alexandru Georgescu, who cast his ballot for the National Peasants Party, one of Romania's old parties which was dissolved by the Communists in 1947. Georgescu, who also was supervising voting at the Dorobanti polling station in downtown Bucharest, said some 45 out of 3,600 registered voters in the district cast ballots in the first half hour after the polls opened. ``We're voting for our future and happiness. We hope to get higher pensions and more medicines,'' Vasile Asafiei, a pensioner, told The Associated Press. The elections drew about 500 foreign observers and the attention of a world eager to see whether Romania is truly on the road to democracy. Government officials promised that it would be a clean election. Some feared Romania's history of election fraud and intimidation would be repeated, including protesters who have a held a four-week demonstration against the interim government and blocked the city's main thoroughfare. But others said the secret balloting for president and a two-chamber Parliament will be fair. ``The world is watching and that has a cooling effect on those with hot heads, and it gives a powerful push for those people who want tolerance and fair elections,'' said one observer, Jim King, senior vice president of Northeastern University in Boston. Gen. Corneliu Diamandescu, first deputy interior minister, told the daily Tineretul Liber Saturday that 40,000 police and army troops would be deployed at polling centers to ``prevent or neutralize manifestations of disorder, acts of hooliganism, violence or rumors which could provoke panic.'' The first preliminary results were not expected until Monday, and the final official tally is due to be released Friday. State-run television devoted its entire evening news program Saturday to coverage of the election and promises by officials that they would be fair. A government statement exhorted the more than 16 million eligible voters to turn out for the first democratic election since 1937. One American observer, Professor Radu Florescu, read a statement on TV by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., promising that the United States would restore Romania's most-favored-nation trading status if the elections were clean. Romania lost the preferential status in 1988 because of human rights abuses by the regime of Nicolae Ceausescu, who was toppled in December's popular revolution and executed. The latest opinion poll, published Saturday, gave interim President Ion Iliescu and his National Salvation Front, which took power during the revolution, an overwhelming 70 percent of the vote in the three-way presidential race. Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party had 11 percent, followed by Ion Ratiu of the National Peasants Party with 7 percent. The nationwide poll of 2,250 people was conducted May 11 to 18 by what the state Rompres news agency described as the non-government and apolitical organization Dacia. The Front, a loose grouping of former Communists, workers and technocrats, says it favors a gradual move toward a free market economy to avoid high unemployment. The Liberals and Peasants, backed by young people and intellectuals, favor a more rapid move to Western-style capitalist economy. Seventy parties across the political spectrum fielded candidates for Parliament, but only half a dozen had a chance of winning seats. Romania was the only East European country to break violently with its Communist past, and its election campaign has been marred by violence. Several opposition party workers were reported killed, and Ratiu and Campeanu narrowly escaped being mobbed and lynched. Opposition parties have accused the Iliescu government of maintaining control over radio, television and newsprint, thereby denying them unrestricted access to the voters. King said he believed the government had not done enough to stop harassment and intimidation. He said he had seen policemen stand and watch as people were beaten at rallies. ``The Romanian society is not a tolerant society,'' said King, one of 60 observers sponsored by the U.S. Democratic and Republican parties. ``It has no history of democracy, and it relies in many key areas on the government to set the tone and the direction for conduct.'' Campaigning officially ended Thursday night, and as of Saturday night no further violence had been reported. Only the anti-Communist demonstrators in central Bucharest's University Square ignored the ban on political campaigning, repeatedly denouncing Iliescu and the Front as neo-Communists. Many of the 700 protesters in the square on Saturday said they feared the elections will be rigged. ``They will fiddle with the votes in the computers, and we are scared of the outcome,'' said Beatrice Andrei, 23, who has spent 20 days sleeping in the tent-camp in the square. The government Saturday night appealed to the demonstrators to leave the main thoroughfare they have blocked for 28 days to allow traffic through during voting hours. Protest leader Dumitru Dinca said Friday the demonstrators would remain until Romania has a democratic government untainted by links to Ceausescu.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Sudan Struck by Strong Earthquake
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale struck southern Sudan early Sunday, the U.S. Geological Survey said. ``We have had no reports of injuries or damages, but both could be expected from an earthquake of this magnitude,'' said Pat Jorgenson, a spokeswoman for the agency in Menlo Park. The temblor's epicenter was near the Nile River about 700 miles south of Khartoum, capital of the African country, she said. The earthquake struck at 4:22 a.m. Sunday, Sudanese time, or 7:22 p.m. PDT Saturday, Ms. Jorgenson said. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. A 7.5 magnitude earthquake is considered a major earthquake and capable of widespread heavy damage, but Ms. Jorgenson said she did not know how populated the region is.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MENLO PARK
Major Quake Strikes Near Southern Sudan's Largest City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Writesthru, precedes Menlo Park-datelined story, adds details, comments by Egyptian geologist, background on region where quake struck. ^By MIMI MANN
DOC.TEXT: A major earthquake rocked southern Sudan early Sunday near the war-torn region's largest city, which is crammed with refugees. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, but experts said widespread destruction was virtually certain given the magnitude of the quake. Scientists said the quake's epicenter was only 60 miles northeast of the city of Juba, whose normal population of 125,000 has more than doubled with people fleeing the country's civil war. The epicenter was near the Nile River, about 700 miles south of Khartoum, the capital of the African country. Most of southern Sudan is controlled by the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. Western relief workers are posted in Juba and other major cities still controlled by the government. The quake, registering 7.5 on the Richter scale, occurred at 4:22 a.m., said geologist Rashad M. Kebeasy, president of Egypt's National Research Institute of Astronomy and Geophysics. The quake was registered by Egypt's two principal seismic monitoring stations, Kebeasy said. Pat Jorgenson, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif., reported identical data. ``It's such a big quake that the monitoring stations are saturated with data, so it's difficult to get everything precise right now,'' Kebeasy said. ``This is an extremely dangerous earthquake. It is the first time that such a quake has struck this area.'' Kebeasy, an expert on earthquakes in northeast Africa, said the epicenter lies just west of the Great African Rift, an earthquake zone stretching 4,000 miles from Mozambique through the Red Sea to Lebanon. Its proximity to the rift accounts for the quake's ferocity, Kebeasy said. ``Warn people to beware,'' he said. ``We can expect large and very dangerous aftershocks for the next two days,'' he said. The Sudan People's Liberation Army launched its rebellion in 1983, demanding greater autonomy and economic reforms for the country's three southern provinces, whose population is mostly animist or Christian. The rest of the country is predominantly Moslem. Hundreds of thousands of people, mainly civilians, have died either from the fighting or the famine it has caused. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number, say from magnitude 5.5 to magnitude 6.5, means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. Magnitude 7 is considered a major earthquake capable of widespread, heavy damage. Magnitude 8 is a great earthquake, capable of tremendous damage. The October 17, 1989, earthquake near San Francisco measured 7.1 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Kills Seven Palestinians; Rioting Leaves Five More Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with final police report on assault saying 7 dead, 11 wounded. Pickup 8th pvs, `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: A former Israeli soldier armed with an assault rifle killed seven Palestinian laborers and wounded 11 on Sunday. The unprovoked attack caused widespread rioting in the occupied territories that left at least five more Arabs dead and hundreds injured. The assailant, dressed in army pants and a black jacket, confronted the laborers, ordered them to sit in a line, then opened fire, police said. The victims apparently followed his orders because they mistook him for a soldier. The army called up reinforcements and imposed curfews on the entire Gaza Strip and half a dozen refugee camps and cities in the West Bank, confining more than a million people to their homes. But Palestinians wild with anger over the assault on the laborers outside Rishon Letzion, near Tel Aviv, defied the stay-at-home orders and attacked army outposts, stoned passing Israeli cars and blocked roads, Arab reports said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir went on Israel radio to condemn the attack on the laborers and called on Palestinians to ignore agitators who sought to incite riots in the occupied lands, already torn by the 29-month-old uprising. ``We were all disgusted by the terrible crime that happened today. It is a cruel crime without any justification,'' Shamir said. Police and witnesses said up to 50 laborers were present during the attack and that seven were killed and 11 wounded, five seriously. An earlier police report had said that eight Palestinians died in the attack. Police said the shooting of the unarmed Palestinian laborers at a busy road junction was the gravest incident of its kind in memory. They arrested a 21-year-old former soldier who was recently discharged from the military after serving a jail term for defying his commander. Arab reporters said five Palestinians were killed in Gaza and two in the West Bank in rioting that followed the assault on the laborers. Arab hospitals and United Nations clinics in Gaza reported more than 400 injuries from live ammunition, rubber and plastic bullets, beatings and tear gas inhalation. The army said at least five Palestinians were killed in rioting. There were no immediate reports of deaths or injuries among Israeli soldiers. In all, it was one of the bloodiest days since the Palestinian uprising began and could rekindle the violence that had been declining in the occupied territories in recent months. Before Sunday's violence, 688 Palestinians and 43 Israelis had died in the unrest. Police said the former soldier who carried out the attack took his brother's Israeli-made Galil assault rifle. They said he hid in the underbrush near Rishon Letzion, a town five miles south of Tel Aviv, emerging shortly after dawn to confront a group of day laborers. He ordered to sit in a line. Khalil Abu Amsha, 30, a worker wounded in the left arm and leg, said he was in a car that was flagged down by the gunman. Survivors said they thought the gunman was a soldier because he wore army pants. ``We thought he wanted to check the car,'' said Abu Amsha, noting that 20 Palestinians were already seated on the ground when the car pulled up. ``He said sit by your friends. We sat. He said take out your magnetic (identity) cards. He said, `Do you know why I stopped you?' We said no. He said, `Good that you don't know.''' Then he opened fire. Abu Amsha said he managed to roll into a ditch after being hit. The attack occurred about 100 yards from the busy Roses Junction, an intersection outside Rishon Lezion. Arab laborers from the Gaza Strip gather daily about dawn in a field near the intersection to be picked up for construction work and other day jobs jobs in Israel. Police said the assailant gave himself up at the home of a friend. Police said the man gave a motive of unrequited love as the reason for his attack. ``In interrogation, he sounded very relaxed. He didn't express regret. He sat calmly and explained things,'' said Haim Klein, police commander of the southern district. ``He spoke of personal motives that brought him to do this. I don't know if that is accurate.'' Speaking on Israel army radio, Klein said the suspect did not mention political motives, but ``the question arises if they were personal motives, then why did he attack Arabs and not Jews?'' Palestinian leaders blamed Shamir's right-wing government for creating an anti-Arab atmosphere that encouraged extremist acts against Arabs. Faisal Husseini, a prominent pro-PLO activist, said Shamir and his allies had created a climate for anti-Arab actions. ``Even if this man is mentally sick the atmosphere created by such a government is responsible,'' he told The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Sterilize 5,500 Retarded People in Chinese Province
DOC.TEXT: China's first province to approve a mandatory sterilization law for the mentally retarded performed 5,500 operations in the 14 months after the law took effect, an official report said Sunday. Officials in the northwestern province of Gansu said their goal was to sterilize most of Gansu's 260,000 mentally retarded residents by the end of next year, the People's Daily newspaper said. Since the law was enacted in January 1989, Gansu has set up a diagnostic network and required examination for all couples planning to marry. It also has sent teams to villages with large numbers of mentally retarded to ``do ideological work among the relatives and guardians.'' Arid, remote Gansu, one of China's poorest regions, has several large concentrations of mentally and physically handicapped people, due in part to inbreeding in isolated villages. The People's Daily said one county had more than 700 mentally handicapped people, but that medical teams had sterilized 516. China has said it is drafting a national eugenics law to reduce ``the births of inferior and abnormal children to a minimum,'' according to the official China Daily newspaper. The paper said the national law also would bar the mentally retarded or people with hereditary diseases from marrying without first being sterilized. The government says there are 50 million physically or mentally handicapped people nationwide out of a population of more than 1 billion. China does not regard childbirth as a private matter. Healthy parents in most areas of the country are restricted to one child, with the timing of the birth decided by local authorities or one's work unit.

DOC.HEAD: Ministry Rescinds Ban on Male Hairdressers
DOC.TEXT: The government rescinded a decree banning male hairdressers from working in beauty parlors after a court ruled the order was unconstitutional, an Interior Ministry official said Sunday. ``The ban has been withdrawn and things will go back to what they were before in a few days,'' the official said in an interview. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the ministry moved after the Supreme Court ruled last week the ban was ``illegal ... a violation of constitutional provisions which stipulate equal rights for men and women.'' The ministry said May 6 it would no longer issue permits for male ownership of beauty parlors and that male hairdressers could no longer work in beauty shops. The court also overturned the ownership provision of the decree, and it also was rescinded by the government. The decree against men associated with beauty parlors was the result of pressure by Islamic groups, especially the influential Moslem Brotherhood Movement, which has the largest bloc in Jordan's 80-seat parliament. Islamic tradition says men and women must not mingle in public, and women are supposed to keep their hair covered in the presence of strange men. But the ministry ban raised protests from moderate groups. Labor unions, womens' organizations and human rights activists also lobbied against the ban. Prime Minister Mudar Badran's government had earlier bowed to demands by Islamic groups that included banning alcohol on Royal Jordanian Airlines flights to Arab and Islamic countries. But he rejected calls to close down bars and nightclubs in this predominantly Moslem country of 3.1 million people. The Moslem Brotherhood emerged as the strongest party in Parliament when it won almost two dozen seats in last November's elections, the first in more than 22 years. Another dozen independent Islamic activists were also elected. The Brotherhood pledged to introduce stricter Islamic laws, ban lewd TV programs and limit women's freedom, including prohibiting women from working.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Archibishop Dies
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal Trinh Van Can, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Vietnam's capital city, has died of a heart attack, the official Vietnam News Agency reported Sunday. He was 69. Can died Friday at his office in Hanoi, said the report, monitored in Bangkok. A funeral will be held at the Hanoi Church on Wednesday. The report said he was the founding president of the Vietnam Episcopal Council and the apostolic administrator of Hue province, in central Vietnam, and the dioceses of Hung Hoa, Thai Binh and Thanh Hoa provinces, in the north. The Vatican said Sunday that Pope John Paul II sent a telegram of sympathy to Vietnam's Auxiliary Bishop Francois Xavier Nguyen Van Sang. Vatican radio called Can an ``unyielding asserter of the truths of the faith ... (who) with no less vigor defended the ecclesiastical institutions in the painful political and social affairs of the country.'' Can was born March 13, 1921, in Ha Nam Ninh province just southeast of Hanoi. He entered the priesthood in 1949 and was made co-adjutor to the archbishop of Hanoi in February 1963 and elevated to cardinal in June 1979. The Vietnam News Agency said Can had presided over the First Espisocal Congress of reunified Vietnam in 1980, at which an epistle was issued affirming the Vietnamese Catholic Church's policy of serving the nation. The North Vietnam Communists reunified the country after toppling the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government in April 1975. Large numbers of Catholics and other refugees fled the Communist advance in a boat exodus. The authorities have eased restrictions on Catholics and other believers since Nguyen Van Linh became Communist Party chief in late 1986. However, the official Radio Hanoi reported Friday that authorities have accused two Catholic priests in the southern city of Ho Chi Minh of anti-Communist activities and put them under surveillance. The report said authorities on Wednesday decided to force the Rev. Chan Tin to move from his house and stay at his church and to put the Rev. Nguyen Ngoc Lan under house arrest at another location.

DOC.HEAD: Police Stop Mass Suicide Plan in China
DOC.TEXT: Police prevented a mass suicide by more than 100 followers of a peasant woman preacher who said the world was coming to an end and promised salvation, an official report said Sunday. The Workers' Daily said the followers, all residents of a central China village, were prepared to drink poisoned liquor and pesticides on the orders of Xiong Chenhua. The paper said the incident occurred in October in Henan province's Tongbo Mountain district. Chinese newspapers often report events weeks or months after they occur, being concerned less with news than with teaching a lesson. More than 20 women were kneeling on the ground in yellow clothing with red insignia, waiting for Xiong to return from a meeting with Jesus, when ``more than 10 police descended from the sky,'' the newspaper said sarcastically. The other followers were waiting for the women to call them when it was time to take the poison, it said. The brief report gave few details of Xiong's teachings, which appeared to blend elements of Christianity with superstition. It said she had been enlisted in 1985 by an older preacher, identified as Old Woman Chen, who told her and several other women they would go with her to heaven if they cultivated more believers. The women converted more than 100 people over the next few years and collected regular donations, which they split among themselves, the report said. It said that even after Xiong and the other women admitted that they were frauds, the ``embarrassed believers still said they believed.''

DOC.HEAD: Corporations Paying Higher Taxes in Wake of 1986 Tax Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: U.S. corporations are paying higher taxes since the 1986 tax overhaul but many profitable companies still pay less than 10 percent of their earnings to the federal government, congressional auditors have found. The average effective U.S. tax rate for 220 large companies rose from 18.6 percent in 1986 to 27.8 percent a year later, the General Accounting Office estimated. ``The increases ... seem consistent with the intent of the changes introduced by the Tax Reform Act of 1986,'' which reduced or eliminated several corporate deductions in exchange for lower tax rates, GAO said last week. Reps. Donald Pease, D-Ohio, and Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., who had requested the GAO report, hailed the findings. ``We're not prepared to make sweeping conclusions at this point, but based on this report from the first year after tax reform ... we're encouraged that tax reform is having the effect we intended,'' the lawmakers said in a statement. The report found a narrowing of the wide disparities among how much different industries pay in federal income taxes. But the gap still exists. For example, the soap and cosmetics industry paid an effective tax _ taxes paid divided by taxable income _ of 45.8 percent of U.S. income; the rubber industry, 19 percent; computers, 12.4 percent; and automobile manufacturers, 3.9 percent. The effective rates paid by individual companies within an industry group also vary widely, due not only to a company's performance in a given year but bookkeeping methods as well. Chrysler Corp., for example, reported a 1987 pre-tax profit of $1.8 billion and paid U.S. income tax of 11.8 percent. Ford had nearly $5.3 billion in profits and paid 24 percent. General Motors reported $1.3 billion profit but because of expenditures for equipment, showed a negative tax rate of 99.9 percent. A negative tax rate occurred when 1987 earnings were exceeded by expenses. In such a case a corporation could receive a refund of taxes paid in some prior year. (GM had a refund of $1,303,800,000, which is stated as a negative number in calculating the effective tax rate. Dividing the refund by GM's earnings, $1,304,700,000, equals negative 99.9 percent.) Among oil companies, Exxon paid 23.5 percent tax on a $2.4 billion profit; Amoco paid 30.7 percent on profits of $1.2 billion; and Texaco, whose pre-tax income was shown as a $6.5 billion loss because of litigation growing from a takeover battle, paid a negative tax rate of 3.5 percent. Overall, GAO found that 41 of the 220 companies had effective U.S. tax rates in 1987 of less than 10 percent. They included: Warner Communications, 2.2 percent; Rockwell International, 6.7 percent; International Business Machines, 0.3 percent; and Merrill Lynch & Co., 0.1 percent. On the other hand, 44 companies reported effective rates above the 40 percent statutory rate that was in effect in 1987. Among them: J.C. Penney Co., 47.5 percent; Sara Lee Corp., 50.7 percent; and General Dynamics, 106.4 percent. By comparison, the Internal Revenue Service estimates an individual with income in the $25,000-to-$30,000 range paid an effective rate of 10 percent in 1987. Those with incomes above $1 million paid an average 28.7 percent. The GAO report dealt only with how the new law affected individual corporations and industry groups. It did not address whether corporations' share of all federal taxes is rising or falling. A major goal of the 1986 law was to shift about $24 billion a year of tax burden from individuals to corporations. Other government reports indicate the shift has been considerably less than that, due in part to lower-than-expected corporate profits. The failure of corporate taxes to meet forecasts is a key reason that the budget deficit is worsening.

DOC.HEAD: Security Stepped up for Martial Law Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Police drastically increased security overnight and set up roadblocks, but the Chinese capital was calm on the first anniversary of the declaration of martial law that preceded last year's crackdown. The government imposed martial law in Beijing on May 20 last year, just five weeks after students began the massive pro-democracy movement that drew hundreds of thousands of Chinese into the streets. Premier Li Peng appeared on nationwide television then saying, ``The anarchic situation is going from bad to worse ... and we are forced to take resolute and decisive measures to put an end to the turmoil.'' The military crushed the pro-democracy movement June 3-4, when soldiers drove protesters from Tiananmen Square. Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people were killed and thousands more wounded. Until martial law was lifted on Jan. 11, soldiers or police armed with semiautomatic rifles were stationed at key intersections and bridges throughout the capital. Unlike April 15, when armed police ringed Tiananmen Square on the anniversary of the start of the pro-democracy movement, the plaza was open Sunday and full of people enjoying their day off under sunny skies. The scene was very different overnight, however. At midnight Saturday, police set up at least 14 checkpoints at major intersections along Beijing's main thoroughfare, Changan Avenue, and along a major road that circles central Beijing. The police, a few carrying semiautomatic rifles or pistols, stopped bicyclists and cars, demanding identification papers and sometimes searching cars and trunks. At one checkpoint, police emptied a van carrying about six people and thoroughly searched the passengers' luggage. Three roadblocks were set up near the train station. A police officer there shook his head when asked if the increased security was because of the martial law anniversary. He refused to answer other questions. At another checkpoint, a police officer insisted, ``This is normal,'' when asked about the extra security. In the university district in western Beijing, there was no visible security presence. Students sat at roadside food stalls outside the gate of People's University eating midnight snacks, and the gate to Beijing University remained open.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Trip Produces Enough for a Successful Washington Summit
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III brought home from Moscow the ingredients of a successful Washington summit meeting. But he almost flopped on limiting long-range nuclear missiles. According to a senior U.S. official, a cruise deal Baker had struck with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday morning began to unravel only a few hours after the Soviet president had said ``agreed.'' By ``splitting the differences'' on air- and sea-launched cruise missiles, Baker thought he had resolved one of the toughest problems standing in the way of a summit declaration to cut strategic nuclear weapons. He had accepted a Soviet proposal to limit airborne cruises with a range above 375 miles and settled on 880 as the number of sea-launched weapons to be revealed to the other side. The Soviets had taken a stricter line than the United States in the negotiations. Baker met them halfway in return for excluding a new U.S. air-to-surface missile called the Tacit Rainbow from any limitations. The upshot: removal of the elusive missiles as an obstacle in the way of Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. Although the treaty will not be ready for President Bush and Gorbachev to sign at their May 31-June 3 summit, a declaration on key issues might be initialed. But ``the package that we thought had been put together began to unravel,'' the official told reporters on Baker's flight home Saturday night. The Soviets were trying to impose restrictions on the Tacit Rainbow. What had loomed as a success was now in doubt. ``We genuinely didn't know if we were going to get there,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Baker, who had practiced law in Houston before turning to politics, decided the solution was to write a letter. It would assure the Soviets that the Tacit Rainbow carried conventional, or non-nuclear warheads, and should not be restricted under a START treaty even though its range will be above 375 miles. He telephoned Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, his main bargaining partner through four days of tough talks, to describe the letter and also to say if the Soviets tried to limit the Tacit Rainbow the United States would not accept the 375-mile treaty range. Shevardnadze called back after receiving the letter and said ``this is fine,'' the senior official related. The deal was back on track. The problem apparently was persuading the Soviet military to allow the Tacit Rainbow to be excluded. Baker went on to meet with the foreign minister on Saturday and then to announce at a news conference before flying home: ``I think our discussions have resulted in some real accomplishments. The progress we have made here makes me optimistic that we will have a productive summit in Washington.'' U.S. and Soviet negotiators will go back to the bargaining table in Geneva this week to try to resolve some of the half-dozen remaining START problems. These include the limits to be placed on ballistic missiles with multiple warheads and the method of verifying compliance with a START treaty. At the same time, a group of Soviet weapons experts will be here at midweek to conduct parallel negotiations in Washington. A trailblazing accord to end chemical weapons production, meanwhile, is ready to sign at the summit without further ado. Bush provided the impetus last week by offering to end production of binary weapons _ two chemicals that are deadly when mixed. The Soviets met his two conditions in Moscow. They agreed to produce a schedule for the destruction of their chemical weapons stockpiles. And they accepted Bush's demand that the two superpowers maintain small arsenals of the deadly weapons until 40 nations negotiating in Geneva conclude a treaty to end production and implement it. Some 24 nations are believed to either have poison gas or the capacity to produce it. The U.S.-Soviet accord, Baker said, ``provides a real pathway toward a global ban on horrific weapons that we already know from bitter experience actually get used.'' On another front, however, a stalemate is developing. Baker failed to speed up a treaty to cut U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. Bush had predicted a year ago that it would take from six months to a year to wind it up. But the Soviets evidently are reluctant to trim their forces in Central Europe to 195,000 men unless the German army is sharply reduced, as well. The impending merger of East and West Germany is causing anxiety in Moscow. Memories of the loss of 20 million to 26 million people in World War II linger on.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians To Seek Compromise Formula on Monday
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian lawmakers rejected Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's demand that the republic suspend its declaration of independence but planned to offer a compromise, spokesmen said Sunday. In Estonia, anti-independence forces planned strikes at major government-owned enterprises on Monday, but it was not clear how much support they could muster. Similiar strike calls last summer interrupted work at only a few dozen businesses in the Estonian capital of Tallinn. Opponents of independence in Latvia, the third Baltic republic, met in Riga, the capital, to form an alliance. The Soviet army newspaper Red Star said the group included Communists loyal to Moscow, military representatives and law enforcement organizations. All three Baltic republics were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union 50 years ago and now are in various stages of trying to break free of Moscow's control. Gorbachev says the Baltic moves toward independence violate the Soviet constitution. Lithuania has pushed the hardest, and he has halted oil and natural gas shipments to that republic as part of an economic embargo. Lithuanian legislators agreed late Saturday to reject Gorbachev's demand that they suspend their March 11 independence declaration because it would mean accepting Soviet control over Lithuania, legislator Zigmas Vaisvilas said Sunday. No formal vote was taken on the issue, and the lawmakers planned to reconvene Monday to draft a counterproposal, said Victoras Balmusas, a parliamentary spokesman. During the debate, Communist legislator Eduardas Vilkas proposed offering Gorbachev a deal that would suspend or cancel the March 11 declaration of independence in exchange for an end to Moscow's economic blockade of Lithuania, a promise not to use force and removal of some Soviet troops, Vaisvilas said. But most lawmakers agreed that tampering with the declaration would be wrong, Vaisvilas said. That was in line with the advice of Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, who met with Gorbachev on Thursday night in Moscow. Parliament ordered a committee to work out other compromise proposals to offer Moscow, Vaisvilas said. Gorbachev's had refused for two months to meet with Lithuanian leaders. But he relented after the republic offered to suspend some measures relating to the implementation of independence _ not the actual declaration _ in exchange for negotiations. Lithuanian leaders said Gorbachev's decision to see Mrs. Prunskiene may have been influenced by the fact that she was meeting the following day with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Baker was in Moscow to settle the agenda for the superpower summit at the end of May in Washington. ``It's very clear Gorbachev wanted to show President Bush before the summit that he has started negotiations and he is not demanding the same things as in the beginning,'' Vailvilas said. Baker told a news conference Saturday night that the United States was ``encouraged'' by the fact that the two met, but said results remain to be seen. In the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, independence supporters kept a vigil outside the parliament building through the weekend to guard it from pro-Soviet demonstrators, reports said Sunday. Lithuanian radio, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp., said the activists sought to prevent a repeat of incidents in Latvia and Estonia, where opponents of independence tried to storm government buildings last week. In another development, the Estonian news agency ETA said Sunday that Lithuanian, Latvia, Czechoslovak and Polish lawmakers met near Tallinn, the Estonian capital, and recommended that the Baltic states be added to the 35-nation of Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which produced the Helsinki Accords in 1975. However, the delegates were not formally representing their respective governments, so the move was mainly symbolic. ``We are not against the Soviet Union, but it must admit the right to self-determination for everybody,'' ETA quoted Polish senator Tadeusz Klopotowski as saying.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Commandments of Courtesy
With AM-Courtesy Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Here are New York Pride's ``Twelve Commandments of Courtesy'' _ tailor-made to a city of cabs, subways and crowded sidewalks. I will be respectful of other cultures and racial backgrounds. I will be hospitable to out-of-towners. I will not ``steal'' other people's cabs. I will not raise my voice in public (except at sporting events). I will try to be patient and wait my turn. I will be understanding of cab drivers and all those in high pressure public jobs. I will strive to keep my city clean. I will not barrel through crowds unconsciously. I will offer my seat to others in greater need. I will try to be pleasant in everyday encounters. I will try to smile more. I will say ``please'' and ``thank you.''

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Children Votein First Free Romanian Elections
With AM-Romania-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The jailed children of executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu were allowed to vote in Sunday's elections, the first free balloting following their father's brutal 24-year rule. Ceausescu's two sons and daughter are awaiting trial on charges of complicity in his rule. All three have been jailed since December and, if convicted, face sentences of up to life in prison. They were not handcuffed when they appeared at a police station in Bucharest to cast their ballots. Nicu, 40, Ceausescu's youngest son and once his successor, voted first. He spent several minutes in the booth before emerging and dropping a large envelope in the ballot box. Nicu goes on trial next weekend on charges of complicity in genocide in the Transylvanian city of Sibiu, 155 miles northwest of Bucharest. He was regional Communist party chief there until his arrest. Sporting a black beard and mustache and clad in jeans and a dark sweater, Nicu declined to speak to reporters at his first public appearance since being shown on television the night of Dec. 22, just after his capture. Ceausescu's oldest son, Valentin, 43, a nuclear physics engineer, spent comparatively little time in the booth. ``I'm treated like everyone else in prison,'' he said, smiling and looking relaxed in a jogging suit top and jeans. He had long long hair, a beard and mustache. ``It is very difficult for me to say something concrete about the elections. It is good, however, that the people are given the chance to have more options,'' the state news agency Rompres quoted him as saying. Ceausescu's only daughter, Zoia Elena, 38, a mathematician, looked nervous and came out of the booth after only 20 seconds. She refused to made a statement. Rompres said they were allowed to vote ``as they were under investigation and still not sentenced and stripped of political and civil rights.'' Members of Ceausescu's ruling Politburo who face trial also were allowed to vote, the agency said. Ceausescu, whose rule was marked by repression unparalleled in the Soviet bloc, was toppled by a popular uprising Dec. 22. He and his wife, Elena, were tried in secret and convicted of causing the deaths of thousands while in power. They were executed by a firing squad on Dec. 25.

DOC.HEAD: House Leaders Want Bill Passed Before Holiday
DOC.TEXT: House leaders hope for swift passage of a far-reaching clean air bill this week, but only after a likely showdown over whether to make automakers produce non-gasoline cars for smog-troubled cities. Floor debate was scheduled to begin Monday. ``We would like to get done before the Memorial Day break,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., told his colleagues last week. The Senate in April approved a similar bill calling for steep cuts in acid rain pollutants and new controls on urban smog and toxic industrial emissions. Both versions would cost the economy about $21 billion a year when the new controls go fully into effect. A concerted effort to toughen the law for the first time in 13 years began in 1989 when President Bush reversed a decade of White House opposition and announced his support for a comprehensive package of new controls. The powerful House Energy and Commerce Committee _ whose chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., has blocked clean air legislation in years past _ approved a bipartisan agreement on a broad-reaching anti-pollution bill in April. The bill calls for large reductions in tailpipe pollutants but is still slightly less stringent than the Senate version in imposing new costs on the auto industry. It is expected to stay generally intact during the upcoming floor debate, which will include a dozen amendments likely to be voted on Wednesday and Thursday, according to several congressmen and congressional staffers. ``We're pretty well where we're going to stay,'' Rep. Terry Bruce, D-Ill., said of most of the major components of the package, including provisions that will force coal-burning electric utilities to reduce their annual acid rain emissions by 10 million tons. Bruce and other Midwest congressmen had fought the acid rain portion of the bill during the committee's debate but gained only small concessions. Key congressmen and staff members met much of last week and through the weekend in an attempt to work out differences on some of proposed amendments and avert contentious floor fights. The discussions produced a tentative agreement on a proposal that would require use of a cleaner fuel in dozens of cities to curb urban smog and a measure forcing a broader phaseout of ozone-damaging chemicals. But participants in the talks said some issues, including an amendment by Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., to require automakers to build 1 million alternative fuel cars, will likely have to be fought out on the House floor. Waxman's measure would establish such strict smog-pollution controls that automakers could not comply without providing cars capable of burning fuels other than gasoline in nine of the most polluted cities. Arguing it shouldn't have to build such cars because consumers may not want to buy them, the auto industry overpowered environmentalists in persuading the Senate to reject a similar provision. ``The fate of alternative fuel vehicles hinges on consumer acceptance and consumers are flashing a yellow warning light,'' said Thomas Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association.

DOC.HEAD: Shooting May Reignite Uprising, Palestinians Blame Shamir
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials condemned the attack on unarmed Arab workers Sunday and appealed for calm, but Palestinian leaders said the incident would revive the flagging 29-month-old revolt against Israeli occupation. Palestinian activists said the assault, in which seven Gaza laborers were killed and 11 wounded by a lone Israeli gunman, resulted from the anti-Arab climate created by Israel's right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. ``What happened today is a turning point, and there will be more violence if there is no political solution. We Palestinians will not allow this to be a forgotten incident,'' said Faisal Husseini, a prominent pro-PLO activist. He said Shamir's policy of building more Israeli settlements and a harsh policy in the occupied lands and a lack of response to U.S. proposals for Israeli-Palestinian talks were conducive to acts by extremists. ``Even if this man is mentally sick, the atmosphere created by such a government is responsible,'' Husseini said. The killings, which police said were motivated by personal rather than political reasons, triggered rioting that left seven Palestinians dead and hundreds wounded in the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank. The casualties marked one of the uprising's bloodiest days, and Israeli officials expressed concern over the prospect of a new outburst in the rebellion, which had been losing momentum in recent months. Before Sunday's violence, 688 Palestinians and 43 Israelis had died in the unrest. An army spokesman who demanded anonymity said the ``sheer scope and intensity of the rioting has not been seen in at least the past six months.'' The protests have been declining for months, and one recent army statement spoke of an ``increasingly weary population which is only able to give passive support'' to hard-core activists. According to Betzelem, an Israeli human rights group, army gunfire killed 39 Palestinians in the first four months of 1990, compared with 91 in the first four months of 1989. Figures also showed that for the first time the number of Palestinians killed by other Arabs, 37, exceeded the number killed by Israelis, 30, in the first three months of 1990. The Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs were accused of collaborating with Israeli officials. Israel Television quoted an unidentified Defense Ministry official as saying Sunday's violence ``is just what the Palestinians needed to bring the uprising back to the headlines.'' Military governors in the occupied areas met with prominent Palestinians, and the West Bank's army commander, Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, spoke in an Arabic-language broadcast. They appealed for calm and stressed the slayings were the act of a ``deranged individual.'' Shamir said he was ``disgusted by the terrible crime,'' and the slayings were condemned by President Chaim Herzog and many other Israeli politicians. Many warned, however, that the attack would escalate the intefadeh, or uprising, recalling the Dec. 8, 1987, traffic accident that gave birth to it. Four Gaza workers were killed in a collision with an Israeli truck, and Palestinians viewed the crash as intentional. Deddy Zucker, a liberal member of parliament and a paratrooper in the army reserves, said: ``I think today is the turning point in the uprising, from the point of view of the price we will all pay. We have risen to a new point in the uprising ... a new stage.'' In an apparent effort to create new momentum in the rebellion, Husseini and other leaders called a hunger strike, demanding a United Nations Security Council meeting and an international investigation. ``This incident is similar to the days when intefadeh started. To change it into a stronger intefadeh is mainly dependent on us,'' he said in an interview. A statement by Husseini and the other 11 hunger strikers also called for an international peace force ``to protect the Palestinians ... until the establishment of a Palestinian state.'' Riyad Agha, former president of the Islamic University in Gaza, said: ``It is a tragic day. It gives more blood for the uprising. It gives a new mechanism ... hatred. Now there is spontaneous fury. ``In the past, only a limited number defied the curfew. But now women, children and men are in a state of hysteria. I can say that extremism is running wild.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: with 861.
DOC.TEXT: Asked about the study last October, the Justice Department's Executive Office of U.S. Attorneys released its own data for 1988 showing that Los Angeles' percentage had increased to 26, from 22 the year before. In the Justice data for 1988, four of the 10 areas ranked ahead of Los Angeles: Brooklyn with 52 percent; Manhattan, 48; Detroit, 39, and Baltimore, 37. In that data, Hartford, Chicago, Boston and Philadelphia had 25 percent; Newark, 23 percent; and San Francisco, 18 percent. Recommended by Thornburgh for two presidential nominations _ to the federal court and to head DEA _ Bonner has followed some of the same paths Thornburgh traveled when he was a U.S. attorney in Pittsburgh in the early 1970s. Early in Bonner's tenure he mounted an unsuccessful move to take control of the department's independent organized crime strike force in Los Angeles. Thornburgh waged a similar battle in Pittsburgh. Later, when Thornburgh rejoined the Justice Department as attorney general he renewed his own decades-old battle to put the strike forces under U.S. attorneys all over the country. Thornburgh's aides recruited Bonner to sing the praises of the idea to reporters. Thornburgh's success in doing that led to the resignation of nearly one-fourth of the government's top organized crime prosecutors.

DOC.HEAD: New Yellowstone Wolf Study Said to Support Restoration Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Ludwig Carbyn...', to CORRECT attribution to quotation to Peek sted Carbyn.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The return of wolves running wild through Yellowstone National Park would add to the enjoyment of tourists and restore a missing link in the park's ecosystem, experts say. But ranchers, fearful of livestock losses, oppose reintroducing the predators, 81,000 of which were killed between 1883 and 1918 in state and federal extermination programs. Now a 600-page study to be presented to Congress this week predicts little harm to wildlife or livestock near the park if wolves are returned, according to those familiar with it. More important, say the experts, it's time to move beyond speculation of how wolves would act in Yellowstone. ``All of the studies currently going on will not absolve the need to introduce wolves and let them tell us what to do,'' said James Peek, a University of Idaho researcher. Durward Allen, a Purdue University researcher who has studied wolves on Minnesota's Isle Royale for 20 years, says the government is obligated to reestablish the gray wolf ``because it was part of the aboriginal fauna that we are committed to preserving, as nearly as possible, in its primitive configuration.'' Rupert Cutler, president of Defenders of Wildlife, the most visible proponent of wolves in Yellowstone, hopes the latest study ends the political debate over wolves that has kept the federal government studying the predators. ``The government studies show we can meet the needs of ranchers and outfitters while meeting the desire of millions of Americans to see wolves restored to our nation's best-known national park.'' Apart from their aesthetic value, the wolves would rein in an out-of-control elk population that is slowly denuding the park's northern range, Cutler said. In lobbying for wolf restoration, Defenders magazine surveyed 16 North American wolf experts who overwhelmingly called for implementation of the plan. Peek told the magazine that ``Yellowstone is a place where natural dynamic processes are allowed to be restored and perpetuated, and the predation process is incomplete without the wolf.'' In the latest study, Park Service and Fish and Wildlife Service researchers examined how 100 to 150 wolves might interact with grizzly bears and Yellowstone's ungulate populations, such as the elk and bison. They also analyzed control methods and wolves' impact on wildlife in Wyoming, Montana and Idaho outside the park. Members of the Interagency Grizzly Bear Committee predicted there would be little if any overall effect either on grizzly or wolf populations, although some individual bears could be harmed. The study also is expected to conclude that over a 20- to 30-year period there could be a 10 percent to 25 percent reduction in Yellowstone's elk herds, which contain an estimated 31,000 animals, and a 20 percent reduction in bison, which now number 2,000. However, the research also notes that the action of predators increases the general physiology of prey, resulting in increased reproduction. As for hunters in the forests surrounding Yellowstone, the study says sport hunting would not have to be eliminated for any herd or species in the Yellowstone ecosystem. How wolves outside the park affect livestock depends on how stringently wolves are controlled, according to the study. There are an estimated 10,000 cows and 5,000 sheep in the immediate area of the park. Controls currently used in Minnesota and Canada range from traps to poison, and in Montana wolves that preyed on livestock have been killed by Fish and Wildlife Service biologists. A key to the controls is whether wolves are returned under an experimental status, as suggested by previous studies, or on their own, according to Steve Fritts, a Montana-based Fish and Wildlife Service biologist who helped coordinate the study. If wolves returned on their own, they would fall under the Endangered Species Act, which bans killing of listed animals by the general public and restricts federal agents to hunt only problem animals. Under an experimental designation, Fritts said, more lenient rules pertaining to the killing of wolves that leave Yellowstone could be instituted. Regardless of how wolves get to Yellowstone, they belong there, according to Dave Mech, a wildlife biologist who has studied Minnesota's wolves since 1969 for the Fish and Wildlife Service. ``Yellowstone Park is a place that literally begs to have wolves,'' he told Defenders' magazine. ``It's teeming with prey. ... Wolves would add an element to the ecosystem that would help restore it to a more natural state, that would allow the public to better enjoy the park.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds `MacNeil-Lehrer' More Conservative Than `Nightline'
DOC.TEXT: Public television's ``The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' features more whites and males and is more government-oriented and conservative than ABC's ``Nightline,'' says a group that studied both shows. The assertion was made by a liberal media watchdog group, Fairness & Accuracy in Reporting, in a study released Sunday. FAIR president Jeff Cohen said that the PBS show has a ``narrow, pro-establishment guest list'' that ``mocks the original mandate of public television'' to provide diversity. ``NewsHour'' executive producer Les Crystal said the news program agrees that diversity is important ``and we clearly feel we can and should do better in that regard.'' But he disputed what he called FAIR's contention that the show doesn't criticize the government much and asks one-sided questions. ``That's just not true,'' he said Friday. ``We look for differing points of view and have them on almost all the time.'' The FAIR study of ``NewsHour'' broadcasts from Feb. 6 to Aug. 4, 1989, was conducted by Boston College sociologists William Hoynes and David Croteau, who made a study critical of ``Nightline'' last year. The ``Nightline''' report, examining 40 months of the ABC program from 1985 to 1988, found that 89 percent of its guests were men, 92 percent were white, and that conservative leaders were the show's most frequent guests. FAIR's new study, entitled ``All the Usual Suspects: MacNeil-Lehrer and Nightline,'' also compared ABC's program with ``NewsHour'' during the same six-month period the latter was studied. The two professors making the study found that ABC's show has slightly broadened its guest list since the original study, but that ``our hopes for significant change were not met.'' Their ``NewsHour'' study found that of U.S. citizens appearing as guests, 90 percent of them were white and 87 percent were male. The figures rose on programs about international politics, it said, with 94 percent of U.S. citizens appearing to discuss world politics were both white and male. The study offered no racial or gender percentages for guests who were not U.S. citizens. It characterized as ``more representative'' the guests invited when the show's topic was domestic politics. It said that 26 percent of them were women, but gave no figures on the race of female guests. FAIR's study said the show's guest list was dominated by two conservative Washington think tanks, with a total of 14 guests provided by the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the American Enterprise Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Students Learn to Leave Their Ghosts Behind
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tsapatsaris pronounced sah pahtz air' ess
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: The young students remember their native Cambodia in bright-colored drawings and somber prose. At the same time, they're leaving behind the ghosts that hid amid the jungle flowers, banana trees and war. ``When my family escaped from Cambodia, my father carried me and my brother in baskets. We were very young and scared. I remember the loud noise of the guns and missiles,'' wrote Saroun Bun, 13, who fled her homeland in 1983. She and other immigrants from Cambodia make up nearly 50 percent of the student body at Joseph G. Pyne public school in Lowell, where Dorothea Tsapatsaris teaches them English and a little bit about survival. ``I'm no psychiatrist, but you can't see the atrocities they've seen and not have it surface,'' said Mrs. Tsapatsaris. ``They need to get it out.'' Compositions by her students are on display at the city's cultural center and others have appeared in ``Duck Soup,'' a children's literary magazine. ``I knew these kids had seen slaughter ... but they hide a lot,'' Mrs. Tsapatsaris said Thursday. ``I like to get to the core.'' At their core, they harbor bittersweet memories. They wear constant smiles and are model English students, but their work reveals their sorrow. ``I miss my home very much, but I rather live in America because there is no peace right now in my country,'' Sothy Sar, 11, wrote in her essay ``Happy and Sad Memories of Cambodia.'' In the mid-1980s, an estimated 17,000 Cambodians came to Lowell, 20 miles northwest of Boston, attracted by job opportunities and tales from friends prospering in this old mill city turned high-tech center. Sothy was 6 years old when her family fled Cambodia in 1985, taking the refugee's path to Thailand ``until our name was called to come to America.'' ``Everything was quiet and peaceful before the war. In the morning the rooster crowed to get us up,'' the sixth-grader wrote. ``Then the Khmer Rouge came and I saw a lot of people killed. ... My mom picked me up and we ran.'' The running stopped long ago for most of these kids, who today wear sweatshirts and bright-colored knee socks to school. But with just a little prodding their memories catch up. ``Many, many ghosts live in Cambodia. ... The ghosts are of all the dead people,'' wrote one young student. ``The ghosts in Cambodia sleep during the daytime, like owls and bats,'' remembers another. ``They come out at night ... go after people at night to scare them, eat or kill the people.'' Steven Centore, a National Park Service worker at the cultural center, remembers when he served in Vietnam that parents tried to protect their children by warning of ghosts. ``Who are the ghosts? The people who come out at night. Who comes out at night? The enemy,'' Centore said. The students' memories are not only of ghosts. Their drawings also recall New Year's celebrations, folk medicine and the familiar daily scenes that were their village lives. And they remember relatives and friends left behind. ``Dear Brother,'' wrote 10-year-old Sem York in an exercise on letter-writing. ``America is different from Cambodia so much. Do you love me or not? Brother, do you fight in Cambodia?''

DOC.HEAD: Passion Play Keeps Traditions _ With Some Updates
DOC.TEXT: An updated version of the centuries-old Passion Play premiered Sunday, and for the first time a married woman was allowed to portray the Virgin Mary. In another modern touch, Christ's betrayer, Judas, is portrayed as a confused and troubled man, rather than simply a greed-driven mercenary. The daylong play, which depicts the suffering and resurrection of Jesus, was also revised to make changes in its portrayal of Jews. Many Jewish organizations had complained for decades that it was anti-Semitic. Under new casting rules, Elisabeth Petre, a 37-year-old mother of two, is one of two actresses alternating this year in the role of the Virgin Mary. Half a million visitors, including 200,000 Americans, are expected to flock to this Bavarian Alpine village 50 miles south of Munich for the production, which runs through Sept. 30. ``The play is just beautiful. The acting was excellent, and I loved the way the stage extends outside,'' said Terry Blankenship, 35, a physical therapist from Fayetteville, N.C. The audience sits inside the theater, but the stage extends beyond the roof under the open sky, with a mountain backdrop. Some playgoers were returning to Oberammergau for the second time. ``I saw the Passion Play here six years ago, and it was the most glorious experience,'' said Beverly Seamans, 61, a sculptress from Marblehead, Mass.
