The last performance, a special jubilee presentation in 1984, attracted 470,000 spectators, about half of them Americans. ``Seeing it is a way of gaining more cultural insight,'' said Lewis Snyder, 40, of Mason, Mich., who works for a Rhode Island-based travel agency. ``Some of the people I bring here are religious, but many are just curious.'' The Passion Play here dates back to 1633, when the bubonic plague was raging. Roman Catholic villagers vowed to stage a Passion Play every 10 years if the plague abated. When it did, it was considered a miracle. Oberammergau, a village of 5,000, is widely known for woodcarvings and the painted frescoes on its buildings. It is generally quiet and peaceful _ except during a Passion Play production. ``Americans are our No. 1 customers,'' said Erika Heigl, owner of a souvenir shop selling cuckoo clocks, beer mugs, porcelain figures and crystal. All 95 performances of the play have been sold out for months. Among the prominent guests at Sunday's premiere was the U.S. ambassador to West Germany, Vernon Walters. ``I found today's performance enormously impressive,'' Walters said at a reception held during the long midday intermission. Anti-Semitic elements removed from this year's production include the removal of horns traditionally worn on the heads of Jewish high priests depicted in the play. The new production also emphasizes Jesus' roots as a Jew, which were formerly obscured. At times he was referred to as a rabbi. The changes were made at the urging of the American Jewish Committee, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and the National Conference of Catholic of Catholic Bishops.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Urges India, Pakistan to Resolve Kashmir Dispute
With AM-India-Buildup, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States warned its ally Pakistan on Sunday that if it starts a war with India over the disputed territory of Kashmir, it cannot count on U.S. backing, diplomatic sources said. Two U.S. envoys _ Robert Gates, deputy national security adviser, and John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Near East and South Asian affairs _ met Sunday with Pakistani officials on the Kashmir issue. The U.S. representatives then traveled to New Delhi, where they were meeting Monday with Indian leaders. India and Pakistan have fought three wars, two of them over Kashmir, since the two nations were born out of the 1947 division of the British-ruled subcontinent. The division was along religious lines, into Islamic Pakistan and Hindu-dominated India. But Kashmir, a predominantly Moslem state, went to India. In recent months, a Moslem secessionist movement has flared in Kashmir. At least 400 people have been killed since the Indian government began cracking down on the insurgency on Jan. 20. ``Our major objective is to help both sides avoid a conflict over Kashmir ... and to begin the sort of political dialogue which would not only reduce tensions but lead to a peaceful and permanent settlement,'' the U.S. envoys said in a statement. Pakistan's president, Ghulam Ishaq Khan, met with the U.S. representatives for 90 minutes, and Western diplomatic sources said both sides did some tough talking. The Americans stressed Pakistan should do nothing that would start a war with India. If it did, they said, Washington would not necessarily support Islamabad, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. Pakistan is a close U.S. ally, while the Soviet Union is the main arms supplier to India. The U.S. envoys also expressed concern about militant groups spearheading the Moslem secessionist movement in Indian-held Kashmir from Pakistani soil, the sources said. The Pakistanis, for their part, suggested Washington was applying a double standard by criticizing the secessionist groups but failing to condemn Indian forces' violence against Kashmiris, the sources said. Ishaq Khan told the U.S. envoys that Pakistan is giving only moral support, not military assistance, to secessionists in Kashmir, said Foreign Ministry spokesman Abu Fazle. He quoted Ishaq Khan as saying Pakistan has made several proposals aimed at reducing border tensions, but that India rejected them. Pakistan has called for talks on the Kashmir issue, but New Delhi has not consented. Gates and Kelly were unable to meet with Pakistan's prime minister, Benazir Bhutto, or its foreign minister, Sabahzada Yaqub Khan. The two, together with other senior Pakistani officials, are off on a weeklong tour of the Middle East and North Africa, trying to drum up Islamic support in the Kashmir dispute. The U.S. envoys had hoped to meet with Ms. Bhutto in North Yemen before coming to Pakistan but the last-minute logistics could not be worked out, according to U.S. officials. Instead, they met with the president, the army chief of staff, and the prime minister's foreign affairs advisers. Ms. Bhutto, in Cairo, said Sunday ``more steps should be taken to make sure that a peaceful solution be found'' to the dispute. But she also told reporters her country would support Kashmir's independence from India ``no matter what the consequences.'' Both India and Pakistan are suspected of possessing nuclear weapons technology _ India detonated a nuclear device in 1974 _ so the dispute over Kashmir is of concern to the superpowers.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Hits Southern Sudan, But no Injuries or Damage
DOC.TEXT: A major earthquake rumbled through the jungles of southern Sudan on Sunday near the war-torn region's largest city, but officials said there appeared to be no casualties and little damage. The quake measured 7.5 on the Richter scale. A temblor of that size is capable of causing widespread destruction. The official Sudan News Agency said the earthquake caused no deaths or injuries. But much of the area affected by the quake is so isolated that any news might take days or weeks. Juba, southern Sudan's largest city, is 60 miles southwest of the quake's reported epicenter. The region has been hit by famine as well as fighting between the government and the rebel People's Liberation Army, and Juba is crammed with refugees from the 7-year-old civil war. In Nairobi, Kenya, Bob Koepp, a Lutheran World Federation official, said a pilot flying relief supplies to Juba returned late Sunday and said the city had not been seriously affected. He said there was some ``negligible'' damage. ``It wasn't very heavy at Juba. The epicenter apparently was in the swamps and the ground may have just soaked it up,'' Koepp said. Scientists said the quake's epicenter was 700 miles south of Sudan's capital, Khartoum. It occurred in sparsely populated territory controlled by the rebels, who hold most of the southern countryside. Relief workers in two rebel-controlled villages, Bor and Torit, apparently told officials in Nairobi, Kenya, the earthquake caused no damage there. ``It's pretty low area over there, with low buildings and quite remote,'' Koepp said. A crew with Koepp's organization landed in the region with relief supplies two hours after the quake struck at 4:22 a.m. and reported seeing nothing amiss. Late Sunday, a Khartoum airport tower operator said flights to the southern city had not been disrupted. Pierre-Andre Conod of the International Committee of the Red Cross said he had no details about injuries or damage. He said colleagues in Juba had not made their regular radio contact with Khartoum but cautioned that ``maybe they have a problem with the antenna. We cannot say it is due to the earthquake.'' People seeking haven from the war and from famine have more than doubled Juba's population of 125,000. In recent years, hundreds of thousands have died in southern Sudan, an area the size of Texas. Egypt's two principal earthquake monitoring stations, including one at the Aswan High Dam, 600 miles south of Cairo and just north of the Sudan border, recorded the quake at 7.5 on the Richter scale. The U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif. reported an identical reading. ``It's such a big quake that the monitoring stations are saturated with data,'' said geologist Rashad M. Kebeasy, president of Egypt's National Research Institute of Astronomy and Geophysics. ``This is an extremely dangerous earthquake. It is the first time that such a quake has struck this area.'' He said ``large and very dangerous aftershocks'' were to be expected for the next two days. The Richter scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number, say from magnitude 5.5 to magnitude 6.6, means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A magnitude of 7 is considered a major earthquake capable of widespread heavy damage. Magnitude 8 is a great earthquake capable of tremendous damage. Last October's earthquake near San Francisco registered 7.1 on the Richter scale. Kebeasy, an expert on earthquakes of northeastern Africa, said the epicenter was just west of the Great African Rift. That earthquake zone stretches 4,000 miles from Mozambique through the Red Sea to Lebanon. The proximity to the rift accounts for the quake's magnitude, Kebeasy said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Officials `Pleased' With First Hubble Telescope Photo
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with photo comparisons. Picks up 13th graf pvs, bgng: Theta Carina. Should stand
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers captured the ``first light'' photograph Sunday of the Hubble Space Telescope and a scientist said the experts ``were pleased as punch'' with the spectacular image. A camera on the telescope clicked its shutter twice beginning at 11:13 a.m. EDT and the images were relayed to the ground more than two hours later, giving astronomers their first glimpses of the view from the $1.5 billion telescope. ``It's quite an image. Fantastic,'' James Westphal, the principal scientist for the camera used in the first photo exercise, said as one the photos was displayed on a TV screen. ``We are just as pleased as punch at this point,'' Westphal said. ``Our image is significantly better than we were concerned that it might be.'' Westphal said the Hubble image revealed a double star that was previously unseen in ground-based photographs taken at an observatory in Chile. ``We didn't know it was a double star,'' said Westphal, noting that he had expected the first image to be ``an engineering test.'' But because of the clarity of the image, he said ``Boy, we could get lots of science out of this right now.'' The quality of the photo was a boost for National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials who have gone through an unexpectedly troubled checkout and testing period with the costly telescope, which is in orbit 381 miles above Earth. The target for Hubble's first image was a star cluster called Theta Carina, a group of objects about 1,260 light years from Earth. The telescope took two exposures, one for a single second and another lasting 30 seconds. Westphal said the 30-second exposure was chosen for analysis because it gave better detail. Engineers manipulated the images while people watched on television, and it took them over an hour to change the raw electronic data from Hubble into a photograph on a TV screen. ``Nobody has ever done this before, so we had to learn how,'' Westphal said. ``The technical challenge now is to get the telescope in even sharper focus.'' The scientists said that eventually they expect to get photographs at least seven times sharper than the one released Sunday. The image came down as four separate parts of the same photo. Engineers then used computer instructions to enhance the quality of each point of light. The initial look at the photo showed very faint points of light on a gray field. After manipulation, the stars were brightened, the background was darkened and the double star could be seen easily. Theta Carina is part of a constellation called Carina, a word that means ``ship's keel,'' that is visible from the ground only in the Southern Hemisphere. The star cluster is identified in the New General Catalogue of stars as 3532 and is thought to be 3 billion years old. Its distance from Earth is about 7,400,000,000,000,000 miles. NASA officials said the first light photo is an important engineering milestone for the Hubble checkout. Engineers have spent a month attempting to align and focus the instruments of Hubble. They have had to overcome computer problems, a fouled antenna, a programing error that resulted from an ordinary math mistake and an unexplained wobble that still is unresolved. The checkout, said B.E. Stull of Lockheed Missiles and Space Co., the prime NASA contractor for the telescope, has been ``a little more stressful and challenging that we expected. ``We certainly expected some difficulties, but we didn't expect the severity and the number that we got,'' he told The Washington Post. The telescope will undergo another seven months or so of intense checkout and testing before the full-time programs of scientific study begin. Officials said long break-in periods are not unusual for robot spacecraft and the testing is even more difficult because of the precise demands of Hubble, the most powerful astronomical observatory ever put into orbit. Hubble, by working from an orbit above the obscuring effects of the Earth's atmosphere, will able to look at stars in the far reaches of the universe, perhaps to point 14 billion light years from Earth. With its 94.5-inch-diameter mirror and powerful light-amplifying and focusing equipment, the orbiting telescope is expected to eventually take photos of stars that are 25 times fainter than the dimmest object visible from Earth. The best Hubble pictures are expected to have 10 times the clarity of photos taken by the most powerful ground-based telescopes. To accomplish this, the telescope is designed to hold so steady that its motion in any direction would be less than the thickness of a sheet of paper. Its pointing system is so accurate that if it was mounted atop the Washington Monument with a laser gun it could hold a steady light beam on a dime atop the Empire State Building in New York City. Hubble was carried into space last month by space shuttle Discovery. On April 25, it was plucked from the shuttle's cargo bay and left to orbit on its own, 381 miles above the Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Layman Beatified By Pope
DOC.TEXT: Pier Giorgio Frassati, a young Italian who helped the urban poor earlier this century, was beatified Sunday by Pope John Paul II, who praised him as a model for lay Catholics. Beatification is the last major step before sainthood in the Roman Catholic church. About 50,000 people attended the ceremony in St. Peter's Square. Frassati, who died in 1925, worked with the poor in Turin as the northern Italian city grew more industrial after the turn of the century. He also inspired many Catholic lay groups, including Catholic Action. Frassati ``realized his lay Christian vocation through multiple commitments, social and political, in a society in ferment, indifferent and sometimes hostile to the church,'' the pope said.

DOC.HEAD: Kwangju Riots Rage for Third Day; 50 Injured, 200 Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS overline to 50 injured sted dead.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos KWG4,7
DOC.TEXT: Police firing automatic rifles held off demonstrators hurling firebombs at a police station Sunday as about 10,000 protesters rampaged in this city for a third day. Witnesses and news reports said no one was injured in the attack on the police station. But authorities said about 50 officers and protesters were hurt in other clashes, including a student doctors said may lose his sight after being hit in the eyes by a rock. About 200 people were arrested, news reports said. Earlier Sunday, thousands of riot police firing tear gas stormed Chosun University to disperse 5,000 students and workers. Police in combat gear fired hundreds of tear gas shells to drive back the street protesters who charged in groups of up to 1,000 at a time. Protesters tore up sidewalks for weapons and built bonfires at a dozen intersections to light firebombs. About 40 taxis with headlights on drove through downtown streets honking their horns to support the protesters. Citizens in doorways and alleys cheered protesters and shouted insults at police. The battles lasted about six hours and covered an area stretching 1.2 miles from the provincial government headquarters in the city center. The protesters screamed slogans demanding the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo and opposing the United States. In the attack on the police station, witnesses said police fired more than 40 warning shots from automatic rifles to drive off about 50 protesters. The battle represented an escalation in the clash because it is uncommon for police to fire or even brandish weapons during protests. Police trained in riot control do not carry arms, and automatic rifles are considered military equipment, not riot control weapons. It was the second time in three days that police in Kwangju used firearms to disperse protesters. On Saturday, officers fired eight rounds when students attacked two police substations with firebombs. At one point Sunday, dozens of students throwing firebombs at police accidentally set a shop on fire. When a fire truck arrived, the students used it as a shield to continue their attacks. Several students chased by police dashed into a Roman Catholic church to avoid arrest and parishioners rushed outside to guard the gate. Even small children joined in the protest, but students urged them to go home, warning that they might be hurt. The protests began Friday on the 10th anniversary of a bloody anti-government uprising in Kwangju, about 150 miles south of Seoul. President Roh, a former army general, was a key leader of the former martial law government that crushed the 1980 revolt with military force. Kwangju citizens claim U.S. military officials condoned the military crackdown on the 10-day uprising, which claimed 200 lives and left more than 1,700 injured. The 1980 revolt was the bloodiest in modern Korean history and seared the psyche of Koreans more than any incident since the 1950-53 Korean War. The U.S. cultural center in Kwangju was closed down last year after being attacked by Korean radicals 18 times since the early 1980s. American officials plan to reopen the center next month. Student leaders scheduled a funeral rally Wednesday for a student activist from Seoul who died Saturday en route to the protests. Police officials expressed concern that such a rally would provoke more clashes. The deaths of radical leaders triggered violent protests in the past when students felt police were to blame.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Financial Support Likely for Soviet Troops
DOC.TEXT: A top political adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl recently traveled to Moscow to discuss Bonn's likely financial support for Soviet troops in East Germany, a government spokesman said Sunday. Kohl's aides have said West Germany might have to temporarily subsidize Soviet troops as early as this summer, once the West German mark replaces the East German currency. West German willingness to help support the 380,000 Soviet troops is widely seen as one way to overcome any Soviet objections to German unification. The Kremlin strongly opposes NATO membership for a unified Germany. West German financial support, even temporary, for Soviet troops would be a first in the history of the Atlantic Alliance. In an interview with the Bonn newspaper Die Welt, Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said Moscow agreeing to unity depends on economic cooperation between the two countries. Haussmann was scheduled to travel to Moscow on Monday for talks with Kremlin officials, the newspaper said. Haussmann said Bonn wants to help the Soviets in their ``difficult economic reform process.'' In a report with the headline ``Secret Mission,'' the West German news magazine Der Spiegel on Saturday disclosed that Kohl adviser Horst Teltschik traveled to Moscow on the weekend of May 5-6 for discussions with the Soviet leadership. Der Spiegel said Teltschik had discussed ``financial questions,'' including Bonn's likely financial support for Soviet troops and the shaky future of East Germany's contracts to supply the Soviet Union with numerous products. A Bonn government spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, confirmed the trip but denied Teltschik was on a ``secret mission.'' ``East Germany's supply responsibilities to the Soviet Union are to be maintained even after unification,'' the spokesman said. ``We also are seeking ways to guarantee the financing of the Soviet troops in the German Democratic Republic.'' The spokesman declined to say with which Soviet officials Teltschik had spoken. Der Spiegel said Bonn is ready to pay $187.5 million a year toward keeping the Soviet troops temporarily in what is now East Germany. Under current agreements, the Soviet Union buys East German marks in exchange for so-called transfer rubles at a preferential rate. The East German marks are then used to pay for goods and services for Soviet soldiers stationed in East Germany. Until now, goods and services have been relatively inexpensive in East Germany because of state subsidies. Bonn officials say unification poses some economic problems for the Soviets. The West German mark will become East Germany's official currency as of July 2, and East German subsidies are also starting to disappear. That means the overall cost of keeping the Soviet soldiers in East Germany will jump this summer, squeezing the already badly strained Soviet economy.

DOC.HEAD: Armenians Vote in Parliamentary Elections
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the troubled republic of Armenia voted Sunday in parliamentary elections that featured a wide choice of candidates, and runoff balloting is expected in many races, the Soviet media reported. An average of six candidates were registered in each of the 260 parliamentary districts, the Tass news agency reported. Soviet television said unopposed candidates were on the ballot in only two districts. Preliminary results were not expected until Monday, and final results will not be available until later this week. A low turnout of less than 50 percent of eligible voters was reported before midday, Tass said. Few candidates were expected to win enough votes to avoid a runoff, Tass reported. The news agency described the candidates as representing ``all segments of society,'' including the Communist Party and informal groups and associations. Some political activists favoring greater autonomy for Armenia had sought unsuccessfully to delay the elections for six months. The Soviet TV newscast ``Vremya'' said the campaign was marked by a ``tense atmosphere,'' noting the thousands of refugees from ethnic violence with neighboring Azerbaijan, the still-unresolved dispute with that republic over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh and the slow pace of reconstruction from the 1988 Armenian earthquake. One voter interviewed by ``Vremya'' said there was political confusion in the republic. ``All of us have lost our way,'' the unidentified, middle-aged man said. ``We don't know anymore what to do, what to think, what is right and what is wrong. We know for sure that everything has changed.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Diplomats Hurt in Attack on Afghan Capital
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. envoy and a Yugoslav charge d'affaires were injured in a missile attack on the Afghan capital of Kabul, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported Sunday. In a separate report, Afghan rebels claimed they had attacked government positions in southern Helmand province, killing up to 60 soldiers. The MIDIA news agency, operated by the rebel headquarters in Pakistan, also reported the rebels destroyed several vehicles. In the bombardment of the capital Saturday, missiles hit the Wazir Akbar Khan area, where diplomatic missions are located, Tass said. The Soviet-backed government blamed the attack on the Moslem rebels. Official Afghan radio Kabul said the missile attack killed two people and wounded 27. The news agency said shelling in the quarter has been fierce in recent days, and that missiles had fallen near the West German Embassy and on the grounds of the U.S. diplomatic compound. It quoted diplomats as saying the attacks were aimed at preventing foreign countries from reopening their missions. The Afghan insurgents, financed by the United States, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and other sympathetic Arab states, have been fighting for 12 years to unseat the Kabul government. But fighting has been sporadic since Soviet troops withdrew last year after more than nine years of direct military involvement.

DOC.HEAD: Use of Closed State Library by Governor's Family Draws Ridicule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 12th graf pvs, `He withdrew...,' to UPDATE with newspaper editorials. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `Missouri Democratic...
DOC.TEXT: The governor's wife's after-hours use of the state library to help her 12-year-old son with homework has generated giggles and jabs from the Legislature and an apology from her husband. One lawmaker jokingly suggested opening the governor's mansion for public tours the same hours as the state library. Janet Ashcroft won't talk about the 2{ hours she and her son Andy spent in the Missouri State Library on Mother's Day. Her husband, Gov. John Ashcroft says it was merely a case of a parent trying to help a child. ``I assume that every parent knows that there are times when their kid isn't as prepared as he ought to be for school, and what you do is you help 'em,'' the governor said Friday. The governor said he was sorry if anybody was offended by their use of the state library to help Andy finish a report on life in Elizabethan England. ``We've tried not to have an imperial governorship here. We don't ride around in limousines because we don't see ourselves as different from the people of this state.'' Still, the governor acknowledged that other students probably wouldn't have been allowed after-hours use of the library, a reference library open on weekdays to the public but used primarily by lawmakers and state employees. Ashcroft said his family didn't mean to disturb anyone, saying his wife only inquired if a library key was available. A library employee who didn't have a key called the state librarian and both showed up to open the library. ``They got more than they asked for,'' the second-term Republican said. ``It may have been that the person responded over and above what the person would have responded to someone else.'' State librarian Monteria Hightower said her Mother's Day activities with her family were interrupted. ``We don't do homework assignments for children. When the services are closed, they are closed,'' the librarian said earlier last week. The incident drew attention on talk shows and editorial pages from St. Louis to Kansas City. In the Missouri House, Rep. Doug Harpool drew laughter when he proposed an amendment to keep state officials from having the state library opened after hours. He withdrew it, saying, ``Nobody would be that rude again, anyway.'' ``There are extras which come with being the first family. The public wouldn't have it any other way. But people in positions of privilege have to walk a fine line. They should be careful that they do not overstep the bounds into misuse of privilege,'' The Kansas City Star said in an editorial last week. On Sunday, St. Louis Post-Dispatch columnist Bill McClellan wrote, ``Now, finally, we have the first scandal of the Ashcroft administration. We have Library-Gate.'' Missouri Democratic Chairman Gene Bushmann joined in, criticizing Ashcroft's vetoes of funds for libraries. He suggested that Jefferson City's public library might be open Sundays if it had gotten the state money. Ashcroft's office responded that Bushmann's numbers and premise were wrong, that state funding for libraries has gone up and that the operating hours of the library in the state capital are a local matter. Democratic Sen. Roger Wilson offered, then withdrew, an amendment to open the usually closed governor's mansion for public tours the same hours that the state library is open. ``It was an attempt to inject a little humor in this,'' Wilson said. A Republican colleague, House Minority Leader James Talent, dismissed the incident as ``really a small thing.'' But Republican Sen. Bob Johnson said, ``This smacks of preferential treatment at a time that some members of the public think that politicians are too self-serving.'' Ashcroft won't discuss what Andy, youngest of three children, thought about the matter, nor will he confirm it was Andy doing the homework. The governor didn't answer questions about the library visit until Friday, saying he didn't know what happened because he was in church with his other son. And he wasn't pleased with the attention the visit attracted. Ashcroft told a reporter: ``The more you make of it, the more difficulty there is for my children. ... I don't think that helps my children and I very frankly don't think it's a news story.''

DOC.HEAD: European Community Edges Toward Political Union
DOC.TEXT: European Community foreign ministers on Sunday laid the groundwork for closer political integration by 1993 but made it clear that none of the 12 member nations wants a federal United States of Europe. Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins described the weekend talks at Parknasilla, a lavish country resort in southwestern Ireland, as ``a real step forward in defining the shape of a new Europe.'' ``It is quite clear that we cannot stand still,'' said Collins, chairman of the two-day meeting. ``A community complacent with its achievements ... risks faltering and stagnating.'' But officials said there was no question of community nations yielding the right to make sovereign decisions on foreign policy. Instead, debate concentrated on whether more centralized powers should be focused on the 12 leaders of government or the community's assembly, the 518-member European Parliament based in Strasbourg, France. Britain, the most skeptical about the idea of political union, said it was pleased with the modest approach at Parknasilla. ``We don't want to give the Euopean Parliament more powers, and we are clearly not alone,'' said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. France was adamant that foreign policy must remain a national matter. ``Today, in 1990, no one is ready to delegate its sovereignty in foreign policy and security matters,'' French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said. France and West Germany pitched the community into an accelerated program for unity with a joint call last month for ``political union'' by 1993. The meeting at Parknasilla was the first since the community leaders at a summit on April 28 agreed in principle to the undefined French-German proposal. The foreign ministers are to meet again to complete draft proposals for the EC's next summit, to be held in Dublin at the end of June. Britain, France and several smaller nations want the leaders of government to be the focus of centralized power, while West Germany, backed by Belgium and Italy, wants increased powers for the Parliament, diplomats said. Jacques Delors, president of the community's strongly pro-unity executive commission, based in Brussels, acknowledged for the first time there is no hope of agreement on a federation. Ireland currently holds the community's rotating presidency.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Examine Troubled Heart-Liver Transplant Patient
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6, `Mrs. Purcell...', with 6 grafs to UPDATE with quotes and plans for medication. Picks up 7th graf, `The girl...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FWX1
DOC.TEXT: The world's longest surviving recipient of a heart-liver transplant returned to Pittsburgh on Sunday where doctors checked signs she may be rejecting her second transplanted liver. ``I've been in the hospital all weekend so this wasn't a surprise,'' said Stormie Jones of the trip from her suburban Fort Worth, Texas, home. The girl, who will turn 13 on May 31, was hospitalized in Texas on Friday. ``The doctors found her enzyme levels were high, so they wanted to get it under control before it got to be a big problem,'' said her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell, who flew to Pittsburgh with Stormie on Sunday. Mrs. Purcell and Stormie met briefly with reporters at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh after coaxing from the hospital staff, who wanted to assure the public that she was not criticaly ill. She was admitted in fair condition. ``Remember I'm getting paid for this,'' she joked. ``And this is just for five minutes.'' Doctors immediately began their evaluation, which is expected to take several days, said hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon. ``One of her blood level measurements is elevated and typically that is something that happens when the body is rejecting a transplanted liver,'' McMahon said. While she's being evaluated, doctors plan to give Stormie higher doses of an experimental anti-rejection drug she's been taking, said another hospital spokesman, Susan Cardillo. ``While it's disappointing she's had to return, it doesn't have to be an indication of a severe problem,'' said McMahon. The girl received a new heart and liver at Children's Hospital on Feb. 14, 1984, because of a congenital condition that left her cholesterol levels 10 times higher than normal. She was 6 years old when she became the world's first recipient of a heart-liver transplant. Before that operation, Stormie suffered two heart attacks and underwent two triple coronary bypass operations. Stormie underwent her second liver transplant Feb. 20 after doctors discovered hepatitis damaged her first donor liver. The hepatitis was caused by an unknown virus. Stormie's heart did not need to be replaced. The success rate of a second liver transplant is estimated at 65 percent to 70 percent. Stormie's stepfather, Alan Purcell, said Stormie was especially discouraged by the possible rejection since she had not felt sick or had any symptoms. ``She's not doing too good this time. She's a little disappointed,'' Purcell said from the family's Texas home Sunday. ``What do you expect of a 12-year-old child? She's tired. ``She's been through more than most humans will ever go through in two lifetimes. She'd like to be normal for awhile.'' Pittsburgh surgeons followed Stormie's 1984 operation with two more attempts at heart-liver transplants, but both patients died within a few days of surgery. Last Dec. 3, doctors at another Pittsburgh hospital performed the world's first heart-liver-kidney transplant. The patient, Cindy Martin, 26, of Archbald, Pa., died March 26 of kidney failure triggered by hepatitis.

DOC.HEAD: Arab States Condemn Israeli Shooting Incident
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arab states and groups expressed outrage Sunday over the killings of seven unarmed Palestinian laborers by an Israeli civilian and called for renewed protests in the Israeli-occupied territories. The shooting Sunday, blamed on an Israeli who had been dishonorably discharged from the army, set off riots in the Israeli-occupied territories that left seven other Palestinians dead and hundreds injured. Sunday was one of the most violent days since the start of the intefadah, the Palestinian uprising that broke out in December 1987 against Israeli military rule in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Israeli officials themselves condemned the attack, which one general called a ``tragic act by a deranged individual.'' But many Arab officials said it represented a pattern of violence against Palestinians. Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat called on Palestinians in the occupied territories to stage protests in ``every village, every city and every camp of the Israeli-occupied territory.'' The PLO chief also urged international intervention to protect Palestinians against ``the crimes of the Israeli army and colonialists,'' referring to Jewish settlers in the territories. WAFA, the PLO news agency, said the PLO made a formal protest to the United States on Sunday over the incident, saying it held Washington responsible for ``Israeli genocide operations'' against Palestinians. The PLO's permanent representative to Tunisia, Hakam Balaoui, submitted the protest note to the U.S. Embassy in Tunis. In Jordan, Prime Minister Mudar Badran called the shootings a ``criminal act, which is also denounced by all Arabs, all Moslems and all the people of the world who have a live conscience.'' Roughly half of Jordan's 3.1 million people come from Palestinian families who fled or were forced out of their homeland during the 1948 and 1967 Arab-Israeli wars. In Lebanon, Shiite Moslem militia chieftain Nabih Berri, who is also a government minister, condemned the attack as a ``horrifying massacre'' and called in a statement for a nationwide protest strike Wednesday. Egypt on Sunday expressed ``deep sorrow'' over the killings, which it said reflected ``the prevailing climate in Israel and in Israeli-occupied Arab territories.'' ``This painful incident no doubt affirms once more the importance of overcoming all obstacles hindering the peace process,'' Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid told reporters. Clovis Maksoud, the ambassador to the United States and the United Nations from the League of Arab States, accused Israel of have a ``deliberate plan to expedite through escalating violence its strategy to crush the uprising.'' Maksoud said Arab states ``call on the international community as a matter of utmost urgency to take the necessary measures to protect the Palestinians in the occupied territories.'' ``To attribute the immediate cause for today's violent incidents to a so-called `deranged' person is a cynical and arrogant contempt of the facts,'' he added. Israeli police who arrested the gunman said he was distraught over personal problems, including a recent breakup with his girlfriend. His identity was not released pending a court hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Increase Of Tuberculosis, Due to AIDS, Poses New Health Threat
With AM-Second-Hand Smoke Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tuberculosis, a once-deadly disease now largely forgotten by Americans, is re-emerging as a health threat primarily among AIDS patients, health officials said Sunday. Tuberculosis cases increased 35 percent in Newark, N.J., in 1989 over the previous year, alarming health officials who had noted with satisfaction a slow, steady decrease in TB cases over the last few decades. On the national level, TB cases rose 5 percent in 1989 over 1988, a jump largely attributable to the AIDS crisis, said Dr. Philip C. Hopewell, chief of chest service at San Francisco General Hospital. AIDS attacks the body's immune system, and TB is one of the so-called opportunistic infections that can accompany the disease. Hopewell and other health officials discussed the link between AIDS and TB here during a four-day World Conference on Lung Health, which ends Wednesday. About 4 percent of Americans identified as having AIDS also have been diagnosed as being infected with tuberculosis, said Dr. Dixie E. Snider Jr., director of the division of tuberculosis control at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. The American Lung Association estimates 20,000 Americans a year develop TB, which, worldwide, kills an estimated 3 million persons each year. In parts of Africa, where AIDS already is epidemic, tuberculosis is also reaching those proportions, said Dr. Annik Rouillon, executive director of the International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease in Paris. ``The combination of the two is really catastrophic,'' she said. Snider stressed that TB, unlike AIDS, is curable and can be effectively treated, even in AIDS patients. He called for TB screening at drug rehabilitation programs, prisons and wherever else AIDS tests are given. He also said physicians should test for TB all persons who test positive for the HIV virus that causes AIDS. ``It's important we get control of the situation,'' he said. Dr. Lee B. Reichman, director of the pulmonary division of the University of Medicine and Dentistry in New Jersey, pointed to Wyoming, where the CDC recorded no new TB cases in 1989, as proof TB can still be controlled and cured. But unlike AIDS, TB is highly contagious and can be spread by airborne particles coughed up by a person with untreated, clinically active pulmonary TB. Untreated, TB kills about 50 percent of its victims within two years, according to the CDC. The doctors said minority groups in the United States have become increasingly susceptible to TB, especially as the incidence of AIDS among those groups increases. Snider stressed that sustained contact is necessary for TB transmission, although he noted that there had been an increase in positive TB tests among AIDS health workers. Tuberculosis is caused by a bacterium that commonly affects the lungs but can attack almost any organ. For the last three decades, it has been preventable and curable through drug therapy, Snider said. He said an estimated 10 million to 15 million Americans have been infected with the TB germ, but only a small percentage develop the disease since most have immune systems strong enough to ward it off. Reichman noted that most Americans have forgotten about the problems of TB. The CDC says TB cases declined an average 6 percent a year from 1981 to 1984. But, Reichman warned, ``TB is back with a vengeance.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Kills 7 Palestinians; Rioting Leaves 7 More Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to RAISE location of shooting by Israeli; pickup graf 4 `Police who....' INSERTS 2 grafs after 22nd `In Tunis...' to ADD State Department reaction. Pickup graf 23rd pvs `Israeli police...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV2,3,6
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli who was dishonorably discharged from the army shot and killed seven unarmed Palestinian laborers and wounded 11 on Sunday. Outraged Arabs rampaged through the occupied territories in rioting that left seven more Palestinians dead and hundreds injured. It was one of the bloodiest days since the Palestinian uprising began 29 months ago and could rekindle the violence that had declined in recent months. The assailant, dressed in army pants and a black jacket, confronted the laborers at a junction south of Tel Aviv, ordered them to sit in a line, then opened fire, police said. The victims apparently followed his orders because they mistook him for a soldier. Police who arrested the shooter said he was distraught over personal problems, including a recent breakup with his girlfriend. His identity was not released pending a court hearing. Israeli officials condemned the attack, which one general called a ``tragic act by a deranged individual.'' The army imposed curfews on the Gaza Strip and most of the West Bank, confining 1.1 million Palestinians to their homes. But, wild with anger, Palestinians defied the curfew and poured into the streets by the thousands, attacking army outposts, stoning passing Israeli cars and blocking roads, Arab reports said. ``They threw anything they could find at soldiers and came at them with all they had,'' said an army spokesman. ``Imposing the curfew on the rioters was a difficult period in which most of the casualties occurred.'' Those killed in the rioting ranged in age from 14 to 30. In one case, Arab reporters said a youth was fatally wounded when he tried to stab a soldier. Hospitals and United Nations clinics in Gaza said 691 Palestinians were treated for injuries from live ammunition, rubber bullets, beatings and tear gas. Thirteen were wounded, two seriously, by gunfire in the West Bank, hospitals said. Israel radio said 11 soldiers were injured. The scope and intensity of the rioting, which lasted about 13 hours before subsiding around nightfall, was reminiscent of the early days of the uprising, when tens of thousands took to the streets in December 1987. It was the bloodiest day of the revolt since 17 Palestinians were killed in clashes with Israeli troops on April 15, 1988. Rioting broke out then when PLO military leader, Khalil Wazzir, known by his nom de guerre Abu Jihad, was gunned downed in Tunis, reportedly by Israeli commandos. Meanwhile, Arab leaders in Israel announced that Monday will be a day of mourning and that they would hold a general strike to protest the slayings. The army called up reinforcements, and Arabs reporters said Palestinians were barred from entering Israel to prevent retaliatory acts. The West Bank troop commander, Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, appealed on the radio in Arabic for Palestinians to remain calm. Palestinian leaders blamed Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing government for creating a climate of anti-Arab sentiment and called for international help in assuring the safety of the 1.7 million Palestinians living under Israeli occupation. ``The Israeli government is responsible for (the gunman's) hatred and crime,'' said a leaflet by the pro-PLO underground. ``This government feeds it own people from their birth until their death with hatred against our people and their rights for independence and return.'' Shamir went on Israel radio to condemn the attack and called on Palestinians to ignore agitators who sought to incite riots. ``We were all disgusted by the terrible crime that happened today. It is a cruel crime without any justification,'' he said. The act was condemned by a broad spectrum of Israeli politicians, and the 13-member Cabinet considered a proposal to pay compensation to the victims. The clandestine uprising leadership called for a three-day protest strike. Twelve prominent Palestinian activists met with Western diplomats, including U.S. Consul-General Phil Wilcox, and announced a hunger strike. They demanded a U.N. Security Council meeting, international investigation of Israeli occupation practices and ``immediate international protection'' for the Palestinians living in Israeli-occupied areas. In Tunis, a PLO statement called the shooting a ``massacre'' and claimed it was the premeditated act of several Israeli soldiers. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Sondra McCarty said: ``We deplore this senseless tragedy and extend our deepest condolences to the families of everyone touched by this incident.'' She called on the Israeli army ``to exercise restraint and for all sides to make efforts to reduce tensions'' following the bloody clashes in the occupied territories. Israeli police and Palestinian survivors said the gunman acted alone. Survivors said the attacker was dressed in army pants and a black jacket when he arrived at the Roses Junction, five miles south of Tel Aviv. Palestinian laborers gather there every morning to wait for day work, usually in construction. Survivors said the gunman arrived about 6:15 a.m. and approached a group of about 50 laborers from the occupied Gaza Strip. He ordered them to sit in a line and hand over their identity cards when a white Peugot 504 stopped to let off more Arab workers. Fakri Kawara, 27, of Khan Yunis said the gunman told the Arab driver to restart the car and leave the engine running. ``Then he killed him on the spot,'' said Kawara. The man then started shooting at those sitting on the ground. Kawara said the gunman finished his first magazine and while inserting another the surviving Arabs ran for cover in the underbrush. ``After he killed everyone who was sitting there he started shooting into the air,'' Kawara said. Khalil Abu Amsha, 30, a worker who was in the car and was wounded in the left arm and leg, said from his hospital bed that he thought the gunman was a soldier because he wore army pants. ``He said sit by your friends. We sat. He said take out your (identity) cards. He said, `Do you know why I stopped you?' We said, `No.' He said, `Good that you don't know.''' Police said the shooting of unarmed Palestinian laborers was the gravest such incident in memory. They said the suspect is a 21-year-old man who had been dismissed from the army as ``unsuitable for military service'' in December 1988. They said he had spent nearly four months of his 18-month service in the stockade for disciplinary offenses. Although political motives were not ruled out, police commander Haim Klein told reporters ``from what we know now his reasons were personal.'' He said the gunman told investigators he was suicidal after breaking up with his girlfriend recently and said he also sought revenge for a sexual attack made on him by an Arab eight years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Three Blacks, Wound 12 in Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Police on Sunday opened fire on black demonstrators returning from a meeting where they decided to end a boycott of white-owned businesses. Three people were reported killed and 12 wounded. The incident began after thousands of blacks held the meeting in the Thabong township outside the mining town of Welkom, 150 miles southwest of Johannesburg. The boycott they decided to end was 11 days old. As the crowd returned home, police opened fire without warning, witnesses said. Maj. Reg Crewe, a police spokesman, said police used force only after the crowd began throwing stones and setting houses and shops on fire. Three people were killed, according to Crewe and officials at the Welkom Hospital. The hospital also said five patients were admitted with birdshot and rubber bullet wounds. Seven other people were admitted to another local hospital, the independent South Africa Press Association reported. After the clash, youths put up barricades of burning tires in the streets, while police ringed the township. Welkom has been the site of racial tension in recent weeks. Right-wing whites have established vigilante patrols to ``control'' blacks. Blacks responded with the consumer boycott. Black and white mineworkers clashed at a gold mine near Welkom last week, leaving two whites dead and 14 blacks injured. Nationwide, right-wing whites have vowed to resist government reforms of apartheid, the white government's system of racial discrimination. Both black and white leaders have warned that right-wing violence could jeopardize efforts to negotiate a new constitution that would include the 28-million black majority. In other developments: _ A black man was killed and nine people injured when police and soldiers conducted a door-to-door search near the Indian Ocean city of Durban. Seventy people were arrested and a large quantity of weapons were seized, the army said. _ Police said four blacks were wounded when officers fired on a crowd lootings shops late Saturday and early Sunday in Virginia, nine miles from Welkom. _ Five black prison guards ended a six-day sit-in protest at the West German Embassy in Cape Town after receving assurances from the government that their suspensions would be lifted. The five also received pledges that about 400 additional black prison guards and policemen would be re-instated to their old jobs. The guards were suspended or fired for taking part in an illegal strike in March to protest discriminatory treatment. The protesters chose the West German Embassy because President F.W. de Klerk was visiting that country Sunday as part of his nine-nation European tour.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Official Says No Hostage Swap Offer Received
DOC.TEXT: A senior Israeli official was quoted Sunday as saying his government received no offer from a Shiite militia to swap the remains of two Israeli soldiers for Arab prisoners. The earlier report said the Amal militia had informed the International Committee for the Red Cross it was making such an offer. ``Israel has not officially been informed of such an offer,'' the unidentified official was quoted as telling the Voice of the South Radio Station, which speaks for the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia. The official was also quoted as saying Israel and the South Lebanon Army militia would be willing to consider a swap only if it involved three Israeli servicemen captured by Shiite militias in Lebanon in 1986. ``Israel will then be more than happy to negotiate and more than happy to have Western hostages held in Lebanon released as part of the deal,'' the official was quoted as saying. The Arabic language broadcast was monitored in Rashaya, in the Bekaa valley in southeast Lebanon, close to the border strip that Israel controls. The earlier report said the Shiite Moslem Amal had notified the Red Cross of an offer to trade the bodies of two Israeli soldiers for scores of Shiites held by Israel and the South Lebanon Army militia. The report said the pro-Syrian Amal has the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in action during the 1982 invasion of Lebanon. However, ICRC officials in Beirut, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Amal made such an offer more than a year ago and nothing came out of it. ``No new moves have been made,'' one official said.

DOC.HEAD: Fifteen Pro-Democracy Activists Pardoned in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's Emir on Sunday pardoned 15 pro-democracy activists accused of holding illegal meetings, the Kuwait News Agency reported. The activists, all arrested in recent weeks for pressing demands for the restoration of a fully elected parliament, were pardoned by the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the report said. ``The Emir has issued directives to the effect of ending all cases initiated recently against a number of Kuwaiti citizens, including former deputies of the National Assembly,'' the news agency quoted official sources as saying. The arrests began May 8, when veteran opposition leader Ahmed al-Khatib and seven of his followers were detained at a diwaniya, which is a kind of town meeting held in a private home. The eight, along with three other activists charged with distributing anti-government leaflets, were released three days later. The authorities also released on bail a former parliamentary deputy and one other man, but were still holding two members of the defunct parliament. The move came in response to appeals by a number of Kuwaiti notables who met with the Emir, the news agency said. ``They expressed to the Emir their appreciation for his paternal and sincere attitudes toward countrymen who, though they differ on the method of practising democracy, remain good sons and loyal soldiers of Kuwait,'' the agency quoted the sources as saying. The pardon was viewed as a goodwill gesture toward the so-called ``Group of 32,'' the activists who called for a boycott of June 10 polling for the 75-member National Council. They said the parliament was unconstitutional because the Emir will appoint 25 of its members. More than 80 candidates have withdrawn from the National Council race since the nomination deadline on May 9, bringing the number of candidates to 485. The Emir issued a decree on April 22 setting up the chamber as a four-year transitional legislature. It was to assess the country's parliamentary experiment and propose future steps ``with a view to averting the repetition of a third crisis.'' This was a reference to the dissolution of the National Assembly twice in a decade _ in 1976 and 1986 _ after members of parliament verbally attacked government ministers, many of them members of the ruling family.

DOC.HEAD: South Yemen Jettisons Marxist Trappings Before Merger
DOC.TEXT: Socialist South Yemen, preparing for its merger with pro-Western North Yemen, pulled down statues of Marx and Lenin in public squares Sunday. Slogans of the ruling Yemeni Socialist Party _ such as ``No voice can be louder than the voice of the Party'' _ were also removed from government buildings. South Yemen was the Arab world's only avowedly Marxist state after it gained independence from Britain in 1971. But as democratization has swept many formerly hard-line socialist countries, South Yemen has also been making reforms. The process accelerated after the ruling party's Secretary-General Ali Salem al-Beidh pledged himself in November to a merger with North Yemen within a year. Al-Beidh and North Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh have been speeding up their merger plans and are now set to proclaim unity in coming days. As a gesture of solidarity between the two nations, the Yemeni Socialist Party's central committee on Sunday announced it was absorbing into its ranks the Popular Unionist Party, which had been bitterly opposed to the North. The two Red Sea countries fought frequent border battles in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Kilauea's Lava Takes Another Home
DOC.TEXT: Kilauea Volcano's relentless lava consumed another home Sunday and continued its slow, destructive roll through this seaside community. The home of Brent Miller, which burned when lava reached it before dawn, was the 143rd home destroyed in the seven-year eruption of the volcano on Hawaii Island. The residents had evacuated earlier, as the lava chewed its way through Kalapana. Just 30 homes remain in Kalapana; 67 have been destroyed since April 4. Eight homes lay in the path of the lava ``in a very precarious position,'' said Bruce Butts, deputy administrator of the Hawaii County Civil Defense Agency. The flows were fed by lava pouring at an estimated rate of 650,000 cubic yards a day from a vent seven miles upslope from Kalapana.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Newspaper Says Cosmonauts Not in Danger
DOC.TEXT: Cosmonauts aboard the Soviet space station Mir are not in danger of being stranded in space because of damage to their craft, a newspaper reported. A U.S. magazine had reported the problem jeopardized their return to Earth. The government newspaper Izvestia on Saturday quoted Flight Director Yuri Serebranikov as saying some thermal insulation had peeled off the hull of the Soyuz spacecraft but that ``in no way'' will prevent the cosmonauts from returning to Earth. The U.S.-based Aviation Week and Space Technology weekly reported in its May 21 issue that cosmonauts Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin, who have been in space for more than three months, have no reliable way to return in an emergency because of damage to the protective blankets that surround the space capsule. Serebranikov told the newspaper that some of the insulation material had peeled off and could be seen by the spacecraft's television cameras, but he added that there was no urgency in repairing it. During the cosmonauts' next space walk, they will patch the spot, he said. Izvestia described the repairs as ``routine.'' Aviation Week interviewed cosmonaut Alexander A. Serebrov who recently returned from the Mir, and it reported that three of eight thermal blankets had peeled away, hampering the Soyuz spacecraft's ability to control temperatures inside. It said the spacecraft has become cold, and engineers are worried that condensation could cause an electrical malfunction during re-entry. Izvestia, however, reported that temperatures inside the spacecraft were normal.
