DOC.TEXT: Singer-songwriter Steve Earle was leading the pack when about 200 motorcyclists rallied to promote handgun safety. The bikers rode Saturday to a cemetery where 13-year-old Jeffrey Johnson is buried. He was killed in a game of Russian roulette in February. The rally was planned ``to remind the public of the dangers of children and firearms, and remind parents how quickly and how easily a tragedy like this can happen,'' said Phil Chamblee, a member of the Nashville Harley Owners Group. The bikers carried a headstone they donated for Jeffrey's burial plot. More Chamblee said Earle, who has four Harleys, sang two songs at the graveside. Earle, who lives in Nashville, is known for country-style albums ``Guitar Town'' and ``Exit O,'' and a departure into rock 'n' roll with ``Copperhead Road.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers on Lawyers: `Obnoxious' but Smart
DOC.TEXT: Obnoxiousness is the quality lawyers like least in their colleagues, according to a survey released Sunday. The finding was part of a non-scientific mail-in survey conducted by the National Law Journal of New York City and West Publishing Co. of St. Paul, Minn., which queried 1,018 lawyers around the nation. Asked what they liked least about other lawyers, 56 percent cited obnoxiousness; 34 percent, conceit; 29 percent, greed; and 24 percent, inflexibility. The respondents were allowed more than one answer. ``Although these lawyers suggest that intellectual stimulation ... is one of the characteristics they value in the lawyers they encounter, they also think that the lawyers they encounter are obnoxious, conceited, greedy and inflexible,'' said the survey. Asked what they liked most about other lawyers, the most common answers were intelligence, 54 percent, and integrity, 46 percent. Seventy-nine percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with their careers and 80 percent said they would become lawyers again if they had the chance. Seventy-five percent said intellectual stimulation is what they especially like about practicing law. Other answers _ they were allowed more than one _ included an opportunity to use their skills, 58 percent; the opportunity to work with intelligent people, 50 percent; money, 50 percent; and a sense of contributing to society, 42 percent. Asked about the negative aspects of their profession, 56 percent cited tension and pressure; 54 percent said too many work hours and not enough personal time. ``In analyzing the results of this survey, it must be remembered that the sample is not representative of lawyers in all areas of practice or geographic areas,'' the pollsters cautioned. ``This study is reflective only of the attitudes and opinions of the 1,018 respondents.''

DOC.HEAD: Banned Journalist Free to Return to South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Donald Woods, whose book on a black activist was made into the movie ``Cry Freedom,'' is free to return to South Africa after being banned for years, his former newspaper said Sunday. The East London Daily Dispatch, where Woods was the editor in the 1970s, said it had received a letter from President F.W. de Klerk saying there were no restrictions or pending charges against Woods. ``There really does seem to be a new spirit in South Africa, and I'm greatly looking forward forward to coming back to experience it for myself,'' Woods told his former newspaper in an interview from London. Woods befriended Steve Biko before the black activist's death in police custody in September 1977. A month later, Woods was placed under a banning order that prevented him from working as a journalist in South Africa. It was illegal for the media to quote Woods in South Africa until February, when de Klerk announced a series of reforms lifting restrictions on banned people. Woods and his family fled South Africa in 1978 and have been living in London ever since. Woods' book on Biko, ``Cry Freedom,'' was made into a movie under the same title. In Surrey, England, Woods said he was delighted with the news. ``It's terrific because home is home,'' he said. ``I was born in South Africa. So was my great-great grandfather. It's where we come from, so it's a great feeling to know I can go back there without charges pending or other legal complications from the South African government.'' Woods told the Independent Television News network he wanted to further look into the death of Biko. ``I think the great tragedy of Steve Biko is that if he had been alive, he'd be part of the mainstream leadership now negotiating democracy,'' Woods said.

DOC.HEAD: Host Says Former Chinese Diplomat Visiting U.S. Won't Seek Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A former Chinese diplomat whose sudden flight to the United States aroused concern in Hong Kong will return to China after a rest in California, his host said Sunday. Xu Jiatun, for almost seven years director of the Hong Kong branch of the Xinhua News Agency, China's de facto embassy in the territory, slipped away to Los Angeles three weeks ago. Xu's exact whereabouts were unknown. ``He told me that after he rests for a while he's planning to make a broad survey and research on American society. He still wishes to go back to his country and will not ever seek political asylum,'' said Hsing Yun, the Buddhist monk who is Xu's host. Xu, 74, reportedly left without the approval of his government, but Hsing Yun said he believed Xu had permission to leave the British colony to visit the United States. He said Xu was carrying a visa good for up to six months. The monk, who is master at Hsi Lai Temple in Hacienda Heights, 20 miles east of Los Angeles, called a news conference because of persistent questioning by Chinese journalists and published speculation in Hong Kong. Public confidence in Hong Kong's future under Chinese rule has been shaken by the sudden flight of Xu from the British colony to the United States. Xu directed the Hong Kong branch of the Xinhua News Agency for nearly seven years. He has been in seclusion since arriving in California on May 1. ``Because we are friends, I do not have the right to ask why he came or for how long,'' the Chinese-speaking monk told reporters through an interpreter. ``He said he did not come here to seek political asylum.'' The monk dispatched his political consultant, Lu Keng, to San Francisco to bring Xu to Southern California. Lu told reporters Xu didn't want to meet with them because questions might focus on ``touchy subjects.'' ``The first word he said was that he came to have a good rest, asking if I could find a nice quiet place for him,'' the religious leader said. He fended off repeated questions as to Xu's whereabouts. A flurry of newspaper stories in Hong Kong linked Xu's departure to frustrations over the hard-line policies of China's leadership following the bloody suppression of a pro-democracy movement in Beijing last June. On Thursday the Chinese Foreign Ministry in Beijing broke its silence and said Xu was merely ``touring and taking a rest in the United States.'' The explanation failed to convince many of Hong Kong's 5.7 million residents, who have long been suspicious of China's future plans for the territory, which reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. China has said it will retain Hong Kong's freewheeling capitalistic lifestyle for 50 years beyond 1997. But many there are skeptical and fear any opposition to Chinese rule in the territory will be brutally suppressed like the pro-democracy movement in Beijing. ``If a veteran Chinese Communist Party member like Xu found himself disillusioned, what else do the ordinary people here have to count on?'' asked political analyst T.L. Tsim in Hong Kong. In 1983, when Xu arrived in Hong Kong, he was the highest-ranked Chinese official ever named to head the Xinhua office. He was a member of the party's central committee, and was reported to have been personally selected for the job by China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping. His assignment was to prepare Hong Kong for its eventual return to China. He gradually cultivated an extensive network of contacts, particularly among businessmen and the media.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in South, Northeast; Torrential Showers Trigger Arkansas Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms fell Sunday over the south-central United States, the Southeast and the Northeast after torrential rains triggered severe flooding in Hot Springs, Ark. Showers fell over much of the Northwest. Snow fell at higher elevations of northern California and western Nevada; it was heavy over California's northern Sierra Nevada and Nevada's portion of Lake Tahoe. Showers and thunderstorms fell over eastern Texas, northern Alabama, middle Tennessee, north-central Florida and southwestern Georgia. A tornado watch was in effect in sections of northeastern Texas, northern Louisiana and southern Arkansas. Severe thunderstorm watches were posted for southeastern Texas and parts of Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia. Flash flood watches were in effect in northern Alabama and central and southwestern Arkansas. Overnight thunderstorms in Arkansas drenched the Hot Springs area with nearly 12 inches of rain, including 4.6 inches in just three hours Saturday night. The severe flooding that ensued caused heavy damage in the resort city's business district; cars and several bridges were washed away. Little Rock received 2.31 inches of rain Saturday, drowning the record for the date of 2.23 inches set in 1928. Saturday night's thunderstorms were accompanied by seven tornadoes, including four in Arkansas, in the south-central United States. There were more than 60 reports of hail, including nearly 50 in Oklahoma, and damaging winds. In Oklahoma, hail as big as baseballs fell near Cushing and winds gusted to 75 mph in Pryor. On Sunday, thunderstorms and showers extended from north-central North Carolina to the upper Ohio Valley and from the lower Great Lakes region to southern and central New England. Flood watches were in effect for southern Vermont and parts of eastern New York. Showers and a few thunderstorms also fell over central Nebraska and south-central South Dakota. Rain showers fell in Washington state, Oregon, Idaho, western Montana and northern California. Sunny skies prevailed from west Texas to Southern California and southern Nevada. Strong winds prevailed over the Southeast and the south-central region. Strong winds also blew over the southern High Plains and the upper Great Lakes. Subfreezing temperatures were reported in Nevada's Great Basin and the Rockies. The low for the nation Sunday morning was 23 degrees in Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Vote in First Free Elections Since 1937
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 6th graf, `Iliescu had...' to UPDATE with comments from opposition candidates. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Ballot counting...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XBUC6,11,12,43
DOC.TEXT: Excited Romanians voted Sunday in their first free elections in 53 years, and a West German exit poll predicted an overwhelming victory for interim President Ion Iliescu and his National Salvation Front. The projection, based on an exit poll of 16,000 voters, was announced on nationwide television while voters were still casting ballots early Monday. According to the poll, Iliescu won 83 percent of the votes for president, while his challengers _ the National Liberal Party's Radu Campeanu and the National Peasant Party's Ion Ratiu _ won 11 percent and six percent respectively. In the vote for the two-chamber parliament, the Front won a projected 66 percent, with no other party winning more than 10 percent. The exit poll was conducted by the West German INFAS, a polling group, at the invitation of the government. If the exit poll proves correct, the Front will not have to form a coalition, but will be able to govern alone. Iliescu had no comment on the poll, the state news agency Rompress reported. But he praised citizens for their high turnout and calm behavior. He said foreign observers were able to see ``the virtues of Sunday's truly free elections.'' Campeanu and Ratiu quickly condemned the poll. ``I find the (projected) results exaggerated, monstrously so. They remind me of the returns in Ceausescu's time,'' Campeanu told Rompress, referring to Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. ``I do not believe they are fair,'' Ratiu said. ``I cannot imagine that 83 percent of the Romanian people voted for Mr. Iliescu.'' Ratiu said there were numerous instances of voter fraud but presented no firm evidence. Ballot counting was to begin Monday and preliminary results were expected Tuesday. Final returns are to be announced Friday. Slow-moving lines of 200 people or more snaked out of voting centers on the clear, windy day as voters chose an heir to the revolution that ousted the iron-fisted Ceausescu. The almost 16 million registered voters were choosing a president and 506 representatives to the parliament. At several Bucharest polling stations, crowds of up to 500 waited patiently to vote after a midnight deadline for polls to close. The original closing time of 11 p.m. was extended earlier in the evening when it became clear that the voting was proceeding much slower than expected, especially in the capital of Bucharest. ``Seeing this number of people willing to stand in line at this time of night gives me great encouragement for this democracy,'' said New Mexico Gov. Garrey E. Carruthers, leader of the U.S. Presidential Observer Delegation, as he visited polling stations in a downtown Bucharest high school. ``I am voting for the first time in free Romania,'' said a beaming Ioan Hurmuzachi, 67, waiting outside a Bucharest polling center. ``I voted in the past under Ceausescu, but it was very clear it was not real voting.'' His comments appeared to reflect a universal joy among voters casting ballots in the first free election since 1937. More than 80 parties ran candidates for parliament, but only half a dozen were considered likely to win seats in the election, which was by proportional representation. Iliescu had been heavily favored to win the presidency. His Front _ a loose grouping of former Communists, workers and technocrats that has dominated government since December's revolution _ had also been expected to lead in the parliamentary vote. The National Peasant Party and National Liberal Party have emerged as the primary opposition to the Front. But the poll by INFAS, a respected West German institute, gave the Liberals only 9.5 percent to 10 percent of the parliamentary vote, and the Peasants' Party just 3.5 percent to 4 percent. No margin of error was given. The election was viewed internationally as a test of whether Romania's interim government _ which included many former Communists _ has truly embraced democracy. Some 500 foreign observers fanned out across the country to monitor the election, which opposition parties repeatedly charged had been unfair due to the Front's domination of politics and media. Ratiu said before casting his ballot in Bucharest that ``the run-up to the election had been totally undemocratic.'' Campeanu, also voting in the capital, called the elections ``a great feat'' but added ``there is a fear they will be rigged.'' Romania is the only country in Eastern Europe to overthrow its Communist government through a violent revolution. Although the pre-election campaign occasionally turned violent, no incidents were reported Sunday. Thousands of police and soldiers were dispatched to keep order around polling centers. The biggest difficulty with the vote appeared to be moving people through the polling stations quickly. Authorities said voters took longer than expected to fill in the complex ballots, and there were apparently not enough voting booths. State-run radio and television reported isolated incidents of pre-stamped ballots being discovered in Bucharest and Cluj. It did not give details. In Brasov, 100 miles north of Bucharest, some voting centers ran out of ballots by mid-afternoon, the county electoral bureau reported. Voters were forced to wait while officials transferred extra ballots from other sites and ordered an emergency printing of 10,000 more ballots. The officials said the situation occurred because many people received permission to vote outside their hometowns and cast their ballots in Brasov. The main issues of the campaign included moving Romania's centralized socialist system to a free-market economy and dismantling the Communist system. Industrial workers, more than 40 percent of the labor force, have strongly opposed a rapid change to capitalism, fearing it could promote unemployment. Opposition parties have claimed Iliescu will continue the Communist system under a new name. Another issue was Romania's ethnic minorities, especially the 2 million ethnic Hungarians, who have complained of discrimination. Tensions between Romanians and ethnic Hungarians exploded in March, when six people were killed in clashes. Among those voting Sunday in Bucharest were Ceausescu's two sons and daughter. The children _ Nicu, Valentin and Zoia Elena _ are under investigation for crimes connected to their father's 24-year reign and the revolution. Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed after the revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Smoke Bombs, Firecrackers at Hotel Before Quayle Arrival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to UPDATE with Quayle giving speech.
DOC.TEXT: Smoke bombs and firecrackers were set off in the lobby of a hotel Sunday, two hours before Vice President Dan Quayle was due to address a Jewish group. Quayle hadn't arrived at the Sheraton Centre hotel when the devices were set off, said John Mulligan, a Fire Department spokesman. There was nothing concrete to link the explosions to Quayle's visit, said Special Agent Allan Cramer, a Secret Service spokesman. There was no fire and no injuries were reported. Smoke in the rear of the hotel's main lobby and a loud explosion were reported to fire officials at 4:41 p.m., Mulligan said. The explosion, possibly from M-80 firecrackers, blew some of the tiles out of the lobby ceiling, he said. The lobby was evacuated, he said. Quayle delivered his speech to The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America at about 6:30 p.m. without incident.

DOC.HEAD: Dominican Officials Suspend Vote Count Amid Charges of Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Election officials suspended the vote count Sunday in a close presidential race at the urging of former President Jimmy Carter after charges of vote fraud. In a televised announcement, Electoral Board officials read a letter from Carter, who was an international observer to Wednesday's balloting. The letter, recommended a halt in the vote count while voter tallies from several municipalities are reviewed. Juan Bosch, 80, has accused his longtime political rival, incumbent President Joaquin Balaguer, 83, of widespread fraud. Balaguer, a conservative, held a 0.5 percent lead after results were counted from at least 93 percent of the polling stations. Bosch, though an avowed Marxist, campaigned on a moderate platform. Bosch threatened to call for civil disturbances in protest until election officials agreed to verify the vote count by comparing tally sheets obtained by political parties at the polling stations with those received by elections officials. That review began Saturday. Electoral Board president Froilan Tavares said Sunday the vote count would be suspended until the review was completed. In his letter, Carter said he was returning to observe the laborious process on May 25. Tavares said mistakes were committed in several municipalities which did not return complete tally sheets or had turned in tallies unsigned by local election delegates, as is required by the election Board. He said there were also other unspecified ``errors.'' Tavares said the process of rechecking was expected to take several days. Before returning to the United States on Friday, Carter said he had no evidence of fraud but said it was possible that ``honest errors'' were committed.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, 50 Wounded in Attack on Moslems in Senegal
DOC.TEXT: Two hand grenades were tossed into a group of praying Moslems, killing two people and wounding about 50, Radio Senegal said Sunday. The radio said the attack occurred Saturday, the second in less than a week in the Casamance region of southwestern Senegal. On Thursday, armed men attacked a magistrate's office, killing his chauffeur. Both attacks occurred near Ziguinchor, 250 miles south of Dakar, in Casamance, the region of this West African nation separated from the rest of the Senegal by English-speaking Gambia. No arrests were reported, and no explanation given for the attacks. In the 1980s, a separatist group frequently clashed with security forces in the region. More than 100 members of the movement were killed and hundreds detained before the movement was suppressed.

DOC.HEAD: He'd Fly Around the World, Landing Only on Water
DOC.TEXT: A seaplane enthusiast took off Sunday in ``perfect weather'' _ a rain shower _ in his second attempt to be the first to fly around the world landing only on water. Leaving a dock on Lake Washington, pilot Tom Casey nearly damaged a pontoon because of a fouled rudder line that caused the one-engine plane to turn toward the shore. Casey killed the engine quickly, and the plane gently bumped into the rocks. After a moment to free the line, he restarted the engine and was airborne shortly before 11 a.m. PDT. Moments earlier, the former Seattle ski equipment and clothing manufacturer shrugged off the intermittent rain. ``Oh, this is perfect weather,'' Casey said. Casey, 53, of Everett, said he had sunk everything he owns and has borrowed $40,000 more to make the attempt. He estimated total costs at more than $500,000, and has lined up sponsors to provide money and materials. Casey's Cessna U206-G Stationaire II, painted red, white and blue and dubbed ``Liberty II,'' was modified with tougher floats and a more powerful engine and propeller. ``The security is my biggest concern. I'm not leaving this plane alone, I'll tell you that,'' he said. ``I'll sleep in it if I have to.'' His circumnavigation attempt on a west-to-east route last year ended about halfway when Liberty I overturned in a windstorm while parked in Reykjavik, Iceland. Casey said he expected to fly an average of six or seven hours a day and about half the distance alone. The rest he plans to fly with observers, including a government-supplied navigator required for all flights that are not on commercial air routes over the Soviet Union. He expects to make 80 takeoffs and landings on oceans, lakes and rivers on a route to Anchorage, Alaska, across the Soviet Union through Moscow and Leningrad, over Scandinavia to London, north to Iceland and Greenland, south again to Maine and then through the South and Midwest. His return is set for a day before the opening of the Goodwill Games in Seattle on July 21. The toughest part is the 12-stop, 6,000-mile Soviet section, largely because of the uncertainty of obtaining fuel and any needed parts or service in remote areas, he said. If more miles are needed to make the 24,860 required for certification as an around-the-world flight, Casey said he might add a segment or two through Mexico. The distance minimum, the length a flight would take along the Tropic of Cancer, is set by the Federation Aeronautique Internationale, the official world air record sanctioning body. Casey said he had spent two years planning the trip but had been toying with the idea for a decade. His inspiration, he said, was the first round-the-world flight by two Douglas World Cruisers, also originating and ending in Seattle, in 1924. Casey dismissed the notion that around-the-world flights to set various records were becoming passe. ``I'll be indirectly blazing a trail,'' Casey said. ``If I can do it in a float plane, anybody can do it anywhere,'' he said. ``What aircraft can people relate to more than this aircraft? Anybody can fly this plane. You can go right down and rent one, just take off.''

DOC.HEAD: Officers Sentenced in Sudan's Failed Military Coup
DOC.TEXT: A military tribunal sentenced two officers to death on Sunday for involvement in a failed coup, but the country's leader commuted their sentences to life imprisonment, the official news agency said. The Sudan News Agency did not explain why the country's military leader, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, commuted the death sentences. The report said the two officers, an army major general and a retired police major, were involved in a two-stage coup attempt that Sudanese authorities crushed in March and April. Also on Sunday, 21 other army officers received prison terms ranging from two years to life in connection with the failed coup. One officer was acquitted. One day after crushing the April 22 coup attempt, 28 active or retired army officers were executed by firing squads. Fourteen other army officers were convicted with sentences of up to 15 years in prison. El-Bashir seized power following a military coup on June 30.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Many Issues Remain Unresolved For Upcoming Summit
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf to clarify; NOTE a0730 should have been slugged, AM-Bush, 2nd Ld-Writethru, a0695.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday that despite new agreements on arms control, differences on ``a wide array of subjects'' remain to be debated at his upcoming summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Even though Secretary of State James A. Baker III and his Soviet counterparts failed to make substantial progress on reducing troops and tanks in Europe during four days of talks in Moscow, Bush said he still believes a conventional forces treaty can be completed by the end of the year. ``We've got to get that done,'' he said. ``Until it's totally finished we've got to stay in close consultation'' with the Soviets. Although continuing to voice a measured reaction to the agreements reached Saturday, the president said that, overall, ``I'm satisfied with the progress made in Moscow that we'll have a good summit. ``In the arms control area, there's been some progress. There still remain some other problems,'' including the sticky issue of reducing tanks and troops in Europe, he told reporters traveling with him on Air Force One from Houston to Portland. Other issues of conflict he expects to discuss in the May 30-June 3 summit in Washington, Bush said, include German reunification and regional problems in Afghanistan and Cuba. ``Nobody thought it would be easy, so we're just plugging away on a wide array of agenda items,'' he said. ``The differences will be on the agenda.'' Baker's talks in Moscow resulted in agreement on chemical weapons reductions and resolution of thorny sticking points on sea-launched and air-launched Cruise missiles. U.S. officials said the arms control agreement will result in some kind of summit declaration _ short of a formal treaty _ that would point the way to an overall reduction of 30 percent to 35 percent in U.S. and Soviet long-range bombers, missiles and submarines. The chemical weapons treaty is expected to be ready for signing at the summit in 10 days. Bush refused to clarify conflicting reports about what Secretary of state James A. Baker III told Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene while in Moscow. U.S. officials with Baker denied statements by some sources that he had urged the Lithuanians to suspend their declaration of independence from the Soviet Union. Bush said he would not discuss what Baker might have said in private, saying only, ``We want to see talks going,'' between Moscow and the Lithuanian leaders. ``We want to see self determination of the people of Lithuania.'' Pressed on the U.S. position regarding whether Lithuania should go along with Moscow's demand that it suspend the independence gambit, Bush added that ``There's no point when you're trying to make progress to discuss every aspect of it in public.'' Later, in a speech to a law enforcement group, Bush accused Congress of spawning ``weak imitations'' of his proposals to attack crime after allowing them to languish for a year. ``We must reject those who soft-pedal the need to be hard on crime,'' Bush said a day in advance of Senate debate on an anti-crime bill. He accused lawmakers of sitting on key anti-crime measures he first proposed a year ago. But he also acknowledged that Congress agreed to his request for more federal law enforcement officers, prosecutors and prisons as part of anti-drug legislation enacted earlier. Bush said he still wants congressional action on his call for expanded use of the death penalty, fewer burdens on police in gathering evidence and limits on the length prisoners have for filing federal appeals. ``I urge the Senate and in coming weeks the House to act quickly and build America up by opposing those who would tear America down,'' he said. Senate Democrats have recrafted Bush's proposals and, with the support of law enforcement groups, inserted into the package a ban on the sale and manufacture of nine types of semiautomatic assault weapons. Fred McClure, Bush's legislative liaison, said the administration now opposes much of the package and will push for a substitute version by Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. The president visited Portland to attend a fund-raising event Monday for gubernatorial candidate Dave Frohnmayer, and also for Sunday's dedication of a memorial to Portland police officers slain in the line of duty. The department has lost 21 officers in its 139-year history, the last one 6 years ago, the White House said. Bush said the administration anti-crime proposal he unveiled in May 1989 would help free the country from violent crime. ``Yet for the past year it has gathered dust in the House and spawned weak imitations in the Senate,'' he said. ``America deserves better. So do the 163 police officers who died last year.'' Conservatives and the National Rifle Association are pushing hard to remove the proposed ban on semiautomatic assault weapons in the Democratic bill. Although he has move to restrict imports of assault weapons, Bush has been unwilling to ban domestically produced models. The Democratic package, however, also includes some provisions more to Bush's liking. It authorizes the death penalty for 30 federal crimes, including presidential assassination, and reshapes the sometimes drawn-out post-appeals process under which convicts seek new trials. The bill also fine tunes the nation's money-laundering laws and reverses Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's decision giving local U.S. attorneys control over the Justice Department's organized-crime strike forces.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Takes Pulpit, Leads Parade, In A `Bout With Bigotry'
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins pleaded for peace from a Harlem pulpit Sunday, saying racial tensions threaten to plunge the nation's biggest city into ``a cycle of fear and frustration.'' In Brooklyn, about 100 people organized by a civil rights coalition marched past two Korean-American groceries that have been boycotted mostly by blacks since January. An equal number of boycotters chanted slogans as an estimated 300 police officers guarded the stores and accompanied the marchers, who called for an end to bigotry. The boycott is one of a series of situations or incidents that have increased racial tensions in the city. The most serious involved the slaying by a white mob of a black 16-year-old who went to Brooklyn's Bensonhurst neighborhood with three friends. A jury's verdict in the case Friday sparked further polarization. The panel acquitted a 19-year-old accused of being the mob's leader of murder and manslaughter charges, one day after another jury convicted another 19-year-old of second-degree murder in the Aug. 23 slaying of Yusuf Hawkins. Dinkins, New York's first black mayor, entered the Salem United Methodist Church in a burned-out section of Harlem just before noon Sunday, knelt alone before the altar and buried his face in his hands to pray. Then he stepped to the pulpit. ``When Nelson Mandela arrives, I hope he will find a city at peace,'' said Dinkins, referring to the scheduled visit next month of the South African apartheid fighter. ``Tensions are threatening to plunge New York into a cycle of fear and frustration that could tear us apart,'' the mayor told several hundred worshipers. ``We all come from somewhere else. We came here to escape prejudice,'' he said, repeating a theme of earlier recent appeals for racial harmony. Dinkins praised a group of black high school students who last week defied the boycott and shopped at one of the groceries. The boycott was triggered by accusations that a black woman was attacked in the store by a Korean-American employee who suspected her of shoplifting. ``I believe the boycott can be solved in a peaceful, negotiated way,'' Dinkins added. ``We need to be free to walk on any street, free to shop in any store.'' Dinkins walked out of the church to a roaring, standing ovation. The congregation sang the civil rights anthem ``We Shall Overcome'' as they swayed and held hands in a chain. Later, Dinkins led the Martin Luther King Jr. memorial parade up Fifth Avenue. Several hundred people took part in the parade, which was sparsely attended. ``This year's parade is more important than any other,'' said Roman Catholic Cardinal John O'Connor, who greeted the mayor on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral. O'Connor said he would try to join labor and church leaders in a discussion of the city's racial problems set for Tuesday. Marchers in Brooklyn's Flatbush section Sunday said they were neither for nor against the boycott, but wanted to see an end to racial discrimination and bigotry. As the marchers disappeared down the street, the boycotters chanted, ``What does the fortune cookie say. No money today?'' The march continued past the site where a Vietnamese immigrant was seriously beaten by a group of blacks. Police later characterized that a random confrontation, unrelated to race. ``We the people of New York in goodwill say, `No more,'' Norman Siegel, head of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, said through a bullhorn.

DOC.HEAD: Flotilla Takes Democracy Demonstration to Edge of Cuba's Waters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with radio message received in Cuba, exile reax and details of ceremony, picks up 7th graf pvs, `Coast Guard...
DOC.TEXT: A flotilla of private boats piloted by exiles sailed Sunday across the wave-tossed Florida Straits to rally for democracy on the edge of communist Cuba's territory. Cuban patrol boats were waiting, but there were no confrontations, said Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Karonis, a Coast Guard spokesman. ``It was a very emotional moment for all the Cubans who particiapted in this,'' said Julio Rebull of Miami. ``We felt we were right in front of the wall, like the Berlin wall, that separates our people.'' Although 34 boats sailed from Key West at sunrise, only 24 made it all the way to the rendezvous point about 20 miles north of the Cuban coast by early afternoon, Karonis said. The flotilla sailed parallel with the Cuban coast for about six miles, then headed back across the strait for Key West, said Petty Officer Luis Diaz. Exiles tossed wreaths of flowers and bottles with messages into the water, Rebull said. For seven minutes, a Catholic priest read prayers to a Cuban operator monitoring a VHF radio channel from the lighthouse at Havana harbor, he added. ``By just looking and knowing on the horizon that we were less than an hour away from our homeland, and after talking on the VHF, everyone was crying,'' said Rebull, 53, a veteran of the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion. ``For me personnally, it was the most emotional moment in my 30 years of exile.'' Rebull said the Cuban operator acknowledged recieving the message, but made no further response. The ocean current carried the messages and flowers north, away from Cuba. Coast Guard Cutters on patrol in the Straits monitored the flotilla by radar, but did not provide an escort, Coast Guard officials said. They had warned the exiles to protest verbally but go along peacefully if they were intercepted by Cuban defense forces, and also warned them that Cuba claims a territorial sea extending 12 miles or more from the coastline. The expedition was billed as a peaceful demonstration against Cuba's Communist government as well as a celebration of Cuba's independence from Spain. ``It will bring a message of solidarity and support for efforts seeking democracy in Cuba,'' spokesman Jose Basulto said before the flotilla sailed. Backers had said they expected more than 100 boats to take park. But Diaz said that no more than 51 signed up, and only 34 actually sortied out of Key West. For reasons ranging from breakdowns to not wanting to buck 5-foot waves in the center of the 90-mile-wide straits, 10 of those 34 stayed on this side, Diaz said. It's not the first time Cuban exiles have ventured into the Florida Straits to protest Castro's government. In September 1988, two boatloads of exiles left Key West to protest human rights abuses on the island. Cuban gunboats stopped them 17 miles offshore. Coincidentally, as the flotilla headed south Sunday morning, two Cubans escaping the island on a raft of innertubes were spotted by a pleasure boat in the Straits about 20 miles east of Key West. Karonis said the sunburned pair were picked up by a Coast Guard boat and brought in to Key West, where they were turned over to U.S. immigration authorities Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vows Interest in Spotted Owls, But Also in Jobs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday the jobs of timber-related workers must be considered before forests are cordoned off to protect the northern spotted owl. Rep. Dennis Smith, R-Ore., said Bush promised him Sunday night that he would try to schedule a White House meeting in which logging interests and others could present their case before a decision is made on whether to protect the owl by listing it either as a threatened or an endangered species. ``There's a lot of people who's livelihood is threatened out here. ... I want to hear more about it,'' Bush said during a photo session with Smith. ``We're trying to find out what is the right thing to do. We've got to be concerned about the human equation as well as the environmental equation,'' he said. A federal inter-agency task force recommended setting aside several million acres of forest land as preserves to save the northern spotted owl. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is deciding whether to list the bird as a threatened or an endangered series, or to leave it unprotected. Locally, estimates have circulated that 28,000 timber-related jobs could be lost if the preserves are established and put off limits to logging. ``I'm interested in the owl, very much so, and I'm also interested in jobs,'' Bush said during a second photo opportunity with Washington GOP congressional candidate Bob Williams. ``So we'll try to find a balanced approach.'' He said he was ``determined to come down on the side of people'' and still have a sound environmental policy. ``I want to be known as the environmental president,'' Bush told Smith, ``But I also want to be one who's concerned about a person's ability to hold a job and have a job. There's a lot at stake here in this question.'' Bush was to talk about the owl issue Monday at a GOP fund-raising event. Smith told reporters that if the spotted owl is declared a threatened species, then environmentalists ``are going to go out and find all kinds of owls'' and make more forest areas off limits. ``We don't have an endangered species. We have an endangered subspecies, if even that,'' he said. ``There are millions of owls in this world. This little puppy just happens to be kind of a passive kind of an animal that is being run over by the great horned owl. The bottom line is people are more important than owls.'' Smith said at the White House meeting he wants ``to tell the president what's wrong with the endangered species act.'' Bush campaigned on a platform promising to be the environmental president. So far his environmental record has been more progressive than that of his predecessor Ronald Reagan, but has drawn mixed reviews from environmentalists.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan's President Calls For Better Ties With China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with Shih released. Pickup pvs 6th graf, `Human rights...'
DOC.TEXT: President Lee Teng-hui on Sunday urged an end to hostilities with China's Communist government and released 10 political prisoners to mark his inauguration. It was the first time a Taiwan president had publicly indicated a desire to move away from the 40-year-old policy of the ``three No's'' toward Beijing _ no official contact, no negotiations and no compromise. At his presidential inauguration ceremony, Lee also promised an amnesty for political prisoners. He pledged the restoration of civil rights to previously jailed political prisoners _ including the chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party _ allowing them to run for public office. Nine people imprisoned on sedition charges were released Sunday, including Hsu Hsin-liang, 49, who was jailed last year after returning from self-imposed exile in the United States. Taiwan's best-known political prisoner, Shih Ming-teh, was also released early Monday morning. He had been jailed in 1979 on charges of instigating an anti-government riot in the southern port city of Kaohsiung. He had originally refused to allow his family to sign for his release because he maintains he is innocent, his sister said. Human rights groups claim Taiwan has roughly a dozen other political prisoners. Meanwhile, Lee's nomination of the nation's only four-star general as premier continued to spark protests on Sunday. About 10,000 people, including students and opposition party members, staged a noisy march through Taipei, smashing windows and throwing eggs at offices of the military and the ruling Nationalist Party. Lee heads the Nationalist Chinese government that has been based on the island of Taiwan ever since losing a civil war to Communist forces on the Chinese mainland in 1949. The Nationalists still claim to be the rightful government of all China, and Beijing regards Taiwan as a renegade province. Lee proposed establishing ``channels of communication'' and said the two countries should ``completely open up academic, cultural, economic, trade, scientific and technological exchange to lay a foundation of mutual respect, peace and prosperity.'' ``We hope then, when objective conditions are ripe, we will be able to discuss the matter of our national reunification,'' he said. Reunification is a long-standing goal of the Nationalists. But Lee said before such relations could be established, Beijing must renounce the use of force against Taiwan, end its policy of isolating Taiwan diplomatically, and promote democracy and a free economic system in China. While Beijing previously has indicated it would not meet conditions set by Lee, the speech clearly was designed to reflect Taipei's desire to gradually improve relations with its neighbor across the Taiwan Straits. Recently, civilian and business contacts have been growing between the two sides. The president also expressed a desire to end within two years the ``Mobilization for the Suppression of the Communist Rebellion,'' which dates from 1948. The decree has ensured the Nationalists' monopoly on power by stipulating that legislators elected before 1949 on the Chinese mainland must stay in office until they can return to their ``constituencies'' for re-election. This has presented obstacles to expanding relations with China and introducing democratic reforms in Taiwan. Lee also stressed his commitment to bring more democracy to Taiwan, but his nomination of Gen. Hau Pei-tsun as the new premier has led opposition politicians and intellectuals to question the government's commitment. In recent years, the Nationalist Party has lifted martial law, allowed multiparty elections and eased press restrictions. But protesters closely identify Hau, 71, with the party's authoritarian past and believe his nomination could lead to a resurgence of military influence. Hau was chief of the general staff for eight years before becoming Defense Minister last year. The half-hour presidential inauguration ceremony at the Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hall, attended by about 2,600 people, went off without incident. Lee became the first native Taiwanese to lead the government in January 1988 when he moved up from the vice presidency to succeed President Chiang Ching-kuo, who died in office. Chiang was the eldest son of Chiang Kai-shek, the Nationalist leader who led the retreat to Taiwan four decades ago.

DOC.HEAD: Flash Floods Hit Central Arkansas, Strand Residents on Rooftops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-13, `The storms also ...,' with 6 grafs to UPDATE that four tornadoes hit area, at least eight other bridges washed away; CORRECT that 2 feet of water over dams, sted 3; CORRECT location of Remmel Dam; picks up 14th graf, `Gov. Bill ...' INSERTS 2 grafs after 27th graf, `Elsewhere ...,' to UPDATE with Sioux City flooding; picks up 28th graf, `The search ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HT3,4
DOC.TEXT: Flash floods turned streets into rivers in Hot Springs, Ark., and pushed lakes out of their banks, sweeping away cars and stranding residents of lakefront homes on rooftops in yet another onslaught of high water. The flooding followed thunderstorms that began Saturday afternoon and brought up to a foot of rain and high winds to central Arkansas by early Sunday morning. The water receded by late morning, revealing extensive damage along this resort city's central business district, authorities said. ``Cars have been completely immersed and washed away. We've got a lot of shops and stores that are flooded,'' said police spokesman Michael McCormick. The new floods brought misery to a different part of the region from the rampage along the Arkansas, Trinity and Red rivers that has caused hundreds of millions of dollars in losses and killed 13 people in the past three weeks in Texas, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Louisiana. Floodwaters continued to surge through southern segments of that region Sunday. Floods eased in Missouri, Kansas, Illinois and Indiana. At least two people died in Illinois, and authorities searched for a woman missing in flooding in Missouri last week. In some parts of Hot Springs, the water had reached the tops of parking meters before beginning to recede. The storms dumped up to 12 inches of rain in Garland and Hot Spring counties Saturday night and early Sunday. The National Weather Service said 2 feet of water was pouring over the top of Remmel Dam at Lake Catherine. The storms also brought four tornadoes, including a twister that destroyed one home, damaged another and destroyed a barn in nearby Conway County. No injuries were reported. Hail pelted a number of central Arkansas counties. Floodgates at the Remmel Dam and the Carpenter Dam upstream on Lake Hamilton were fully opened to release water from the lakes into the Ouachita River. ``They've all overflowed their banks,'' said Ralph Lee, assistant director of Garland County Office of Emergency Services. Residents of low-lying areas in Garland County left their homes and sought shelter at a National Guard armory and churches, Lee said. He said there was no estimate available on the number of people evacuated. ``The hardest hit areas are the ones closest to the lakes,'' Lee said. ``A lot of the lakefront homes have been evacuated and the ones who waited too late are on top of their homes.'' Residents were still being rescued from rooftops by boat Sunday morning. The floods caused power outages throughout Hot Springs, and washed away a landmark 90-year-old iron bridge and at least eight other bridges in the area. Gov. Bill Clinton declared Garland County a state disaster area after inspecting flood damage in Hot Springs, making assistance available to flood victims. The county was also added, along with Clay County, to a federal disaster declaration covering 20 other counties hit by flooding, said Ray Briggler of the state Office of Emergency Services. In southeastern Texas, tempers began flaring in flooded communities along the Trinity River, where sheriffs' deputies were keeping an eye on joyriders in boats and recreational vehicles. ``We've had a couple of incidents that haven't been bad, but some of the teen-agers, they want to go out with their four-wheel drives and things,'' said Liberty County sheriff's dispatcher Jo Griffith. ``We go out and talk to them and tell them they're not really helping.'' Waves from boat wakes can cause more damage to flooded homes, and property owners are angry, said Jim Mitchum of the Liberty County emergency management office. Mitchum said 500 to 700 people per day were being fed from the county's emergency mobile kitchen and about 60 people stayed at emergency shelters overnight Saturday in Liberty County. At least 2,000 homes are in 15 to 20 subdivisions in the floodwaters' path, but Mitchum did not have an estimate on how many actually are flooded. Forty-nine families have not evacuated from subdivisions. ``They're staying in against our recommendation,'' Mitchum said. Closer to the Lake Livingston Dam, sheriffs dispatchers in San Jacinto and Polk County said about 100 homes sustained flood damage. Many are under water. Engineers Sunday were still releasing 100,800 cubic feet per second of water through the dam, which remained a foot over flood stage, the Trinity River Authority said. Usually, about 7,000 cfs of water goes through the dam and 20,000 cfs is enough to cause flooding. Engineers expected the 100,000-plus level to be sustained for at least the next few days, Mitchum said. The Trinity at Liberty is expected to crest at 29{ feet, 5{ feet above flood stage, by the end of next week and remain at that level for at least several days, the weather service said. In east-central Louisiana, a dike built by hundreds of volunteers at Vick was credited with saving 30,000 acres and about 300 homes from the raging Red. A similar dirt dike covered with plastic was expected to protect 300 to 400 homes and 50,000 acres of cropland. About 370 people in five northwestern Louisiana parishes have had to leave their homes because of flooding by the Red. The river is expected to crest about 7 feet above flood stage Monday at Alexandria, and the weather service warned residents to be alert. Elsewhere: _ In Sioux City, Iowa, firefighters and public works crews Sunday helped homeowners clean up from a flood by Perry Creek the day before that left oozing mud several feet deep in parts of the city. Three bridges remained closed and two may have to be rebuilt. Gov. Terry Branstad has declared the city a state disaster area. _ The search continued Sunday near Jefferson City, Mo., for a woman who may have been swept away Thursday by floodwaters on the Moreau River. The Mississippi River at St. Louis crested at 33 feet, 3 feet above flood stage, and was expected to drop 6 feet by Tuesday. _ In southern Illinois, several homes in Lawrenceville were evacuated because of the rising Embarras River, which was expected to crest almost 11 feet above flood stage Sunday. _ Rivers continued dropping in southern Indiana. The weather service predicted an end by Thursday to flooding that last week reached the highest levels in more than 20 years in some places. Flooding on the White River late Friday washed away at least 3,000 feet of water lines in Petersburg. People in the 3,500-resident town were urged to boil water for drinking and cooking, and water was brought in by tanker truck.

DOC.HEAD: Pilgrims Sailed in the Pinto? Wait a Minute ...
DOC.TEXT: How's this for revisionist history? The pilgrims sailed to America in the Pinto. Paul Revere wrote ``The Star-Spangled Banner.'' Sandra Day O'Connor is chief justice of the U.S. Supreme Court. And Gen. Douglas MacArthur said, ``Give me liberty or give me death.'' Or was it Martin Luther King Jr.? These are samplings of responses from community-college students to questions that might be asked of immigrants seeking U.S. citizenship. Just five of 119 students at Bellevue Community College managed a passing grade of 70 percent or better. ``This is pretty bad,'' said Aslam Khan, head of the college's political science department, who administered the test. ``Why should we give these questions to foreigners when our own citizens don't know what is going on?'' asked the Pakistan-born Khan, who took such a test when he became a naturalized citizen. Less than half the students knew that the supreme law of the land is the Constitution. When asked what kind of government the United States has, many answered ``capitalist,'' rather than a democracy. Some said the pilgrims left Europe because they were searching for something to colonize, apparently forgetting the religious persecution that prompted them to flee to the New World. A decade ago, Khan gave a similar test of 10 questions to 118 students. Six passed. ``It's not getting any better,'' he said. It may be good for a few snickers when a student identifies Abraham Lincoln as the principal author of the Declaration of Independence, but when only one student answers 29 of the 30 questions correctly and just 18 get 60 percent right, everybody should be concerned, Khan said. ``I think people should know what is going on in this country,'' he said. ``We really do need a course in remedial American Government.'' For the record: _ The Pinta, not the Pinto, was one of three ships used by Christopher Columbus, along with the Nina and the Santa Maria. The pilgrims sailed in the Mayflower. _ Francis Scott Key wrote the national anthem, while Paul Revere warned American revolutionaries the British were coming. _ Ms. O'Connor is the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court, which has yet to have a woman chief justice. _ Patrick Henry preferred death over tyranny in his famous to the Virginia House of Burgesses, while MacArthur is remembered for pledging ``I shall return'' to the Philippines and civil-rights leader King for his ``I have a dream'' speech.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Joins Unprecedented Four-Nation Group
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia on Sunday joined four other European nations in the first regional cooperation group to unite NATO, Warsaw Pact and neutral nations. The other members of the group are Austria, Italy, Yugoslavia, and Hungary. Representatives of the five nations met in Vienna on Sunday to discuss ways of furthering cooperation in transport, communications, the environment, culture and small businesses. A senior foreign ministry official from Hungary and the foreign ministers of the other nations took part in the discussions. The organization grew out of cooperation between border regions of Italy, Yugoslavia, Austria and Hungary that began 11 years ago. It is the only regional cooperation organization to unite neutral nations with countries from the West's North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The four nations decided to boost cooperation last fall, just before a peaceful revolution in Czechoslovakia toppled the Communists and brought a pro-democracy government headed by former dissidents to power. The decision to admit Czechoslovakia was taken in April. Members of the group said say Romania and Bulgaria have also applied to join. Italian Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis said at a news conference that one aim of the organization is to ensure that Western Europe does not become preoccupied with questions posed by Germany's reunification at the expense of other regions. He said the five nations hope to be among the first to apply for investment grants to the new bank for European Development and Cooperation formally founded in Paris on Saturday. The five also intend to present to a forthcoming 35-nation conference in Copenhagen, Denmark, on human rights proposals on minority rights designed to defuse potential ethnic conflicts, particularly those in Eastern Europe, de Michelis said. During an hourlong televised discussion, the five officials each stressed the importance of the group as a way to bring together organizations with diverse affiliations but common pasts and interests. Yugoslavia is nonaligned and in transition between Communism and democracy. Czechoslovakia and Hungary, moving swiftly toward Western-style democracy, are still members of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and Comecon. Austria is a neutral member of the European Free Trade Association, and Italy is in NATO and the European Community.

DOC.HEAD: Students Tell Undercover Police to Just Say No
DOC.TEXT: Undercover officers who went to high school campuses to buy drugs this year say they ran into something never encountered before: students who told them to just say no. All eight young officers who posed as high school students on nine Los Angeles campuses last semester ran into at least some students who advised them against using drugs, Police Chief Daryl Gates said Friday. Officer Sonia Caballero added that some students she approached about buying drugs even told her they don't like to associate with people who are users. Gates said that was the first time in the 17-year history of the department's twice-a-year high school drug-buy program that ever happened. He hopes it means the tide may be turning against drug use among Los Angeles high school students. ``I feel we are moving toward winning our war on drugs on the campuses,'' he said. Gates said police made about 165 purchases from 139 dealers at the nine high schools. He said 120 arrests have been made so far, with more anticipated. Nearly $10,000 worth of drugs, including LSD, amphetamines and psilocybin, was seized. Gates said as many as 300 buys would routinely be made during a semester in the 1970s, when campus drug use appeared to be at its height. But he acknowledged that buys may be down in part because students have become more careful because the word is out that undercover ``narcs'' haunt their campuses.

DOC.HEAD: Tire Fire Near Montreal Extinguished After Three Days
DOC.TEXT:
ST-AMABLE, Quebec (AP) _ Firefighters used sand to smother the last flames of a fire that raged for three days through a dump near Montreal that held 3 million tires, an official said. Mayor Jacques Doyon of St-Amable, a community of 5,000 near the tire dump, said the fire was extinguished at about midnight Saturday. Doyon said the 16 families evacuated from their homes were being allowed to return. On Thursday, Doyon recommended that people living near the dump evacute their homes to avoid the thick, chocking smoke that was drifting toward the area. The town is located 18 miles southeast of Montreal and 50 miles from the U.S. border. The fire began Wednesday and quickly spread over most of the dump, an area the size of seven football fields. It sent up a column of thick smoke more than 4,000 feet high.
Provincial police issued a statement Sunday saying investigators believe the fire may have started in the undergrowth of a nearby ditch. They said the investigation was continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Appearance by Tutu Disrupted by Jewish Militants
DOC.TEXT: Activists from the militant Jewish Defense League heckled Archbishop Desmond Tutu on Sunday, forcing cancellation of an outdoor reception for the Nobel Peace Prize winner at an Episcopal church. The protesters shouted angry epithets at Tutu, prompting All Saints Episcopal Church officials to hustle the spiritual leader away from the area and cancel the outdoor reception. ``Tell him to lay off Israel,'' said Irv Rubin, JDL spokesman. He was apparently referring to Tutu's recent trip to the Middle East where he urged Jewish leaders to forget the Holocaust and spoke out in support of a separate Palestinian state. ``Why do you hate Jews?'' the JDL members chanted. The Rev. Dr. George Regas, rector of the church, said Tutu was not angered by the demonstrators. ``Please let them say what they want to say, because in my country they are not allowed to do that,'' Regas quoted Tutu as saying. Before the confrontation, Tutu delivered an hour-long sermon to an overflow crowd. Up to 2,000 people were turned away and watched the service on closed circuit television sets outside.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Make Last Appearances in Bloody Colombian Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 10th `In the...' to UPDATE with new attack wounding six; PICKUP graf 11 pvs `Death threats...'
DOC.TEXT: Defying death threats from drug traffickers, Colombia's presidential front-runner spoke to more than 5,000 supporters at a stadium Sunday near the end of the most violent race in the nation's history. ``We have arrived here to finish the campaign amid all the difficulties that the violent ones have placed upon us,'' said 43-year-old Cesar Gaviria, referring to drug traffickers. ``We have arrived here to defend our democracy, convinced that the only tool Colombian citizens have to fight the violence is that democracy,'' he said during his speech at the indoor stadium in Bogota, the capital. The rally was Gaviria's last chance to personally addresss supporters because Colombian law prohibits public appearances by candidates during the last week of the campaign. During the race for the May 27 elections, three candidates were killed. In less than nine months, gunmen believed to have been working for drug traffickers have killed Luis Carlos Galan of the governing Liberal Party, Bernardo Jaramillo of the Patriotic Union Party and Carlos Pizarro of the April 19 Movement, or M19. It was Galan's assassination in August that set off a U.S.-backed government crackdown on the traffickers, who responded with a wave of violent attacks. Since August, President Virgilio Barco's administration has extradited 14 drug suspects, killed Medellin cartel leader Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine magnates. Bombings blamed on the Medellin cartel, including urban car-bomb attacks and an explosion aboard a Colombian jetliner, have killed about 300 people in the last nine months. In the latest attack, a car bomb exploded late Sunday outside a shopping center in northern Bogota, wounding six people and causing extensive damage to buildings, officials said. Earlier Sunday, gunmen wounded two pedestrians when they sprayed the police headquarters in the city of Medellin with automatic weapon fire. Death threats forced Gaviria, who replaced Galan as Liberal Party candidate, to cancel recent campaign appearances. Campaign sources said they believed the death threats were from drug traffickers angry over the candidate's promise to continue a government crackdown on the country's cocaine cartels. During his speech, Gaviria repeated his promise to carry forward Galan's reform program, including changes in the country's congress and judiciary. Colombians frequently point to the congress as the governmental branch most corrupted by drug traffickers' payoffs. Traffickers have also severely damaged the country's judicial system by bribing, threatening and killing judges. ``We are obligated to reform our justice system,'' Gaviria said Sunday. ``It must be made effective so that we Colombians can confront the violence that comes from drug traffickers, narco-terrorists and common criminals.'' Fifteen bodyguards, their jackets bulging with firearms, crowded around the candidate as he spoke from a podium 20 feet above the crowd on the stadium's floor. The stiffness apparent in Gaviria's movements suggested that the red parka he was wearing was packed with bullet-resistant plastic. Colombian law prohibits the publication of public opinion polls during the last month of the campaign. But recent private polls have shown Gaviria leading his nearest rival by at least 30 percentage points. Two other leading candidates, Alvaro Gomez of the independent National Salvation Movement and Rodrigo Lloreda of the Conservative Party, also made appearances Sunday at smaller political gatherings in Bogota. Both candidates have said they were willing to end the government's policy of extraditing drug suspects in exchange for traffickers' pledge to end their campaign of terrorist attacks. Another candidate, Antonio Navarro, was not making appearances on Sunday. Navarro, who became the candidate for the leftist M19 movement after last month's assassination of Pizarro, said he has also received death threats. Candidates will continue campaigning this week on radio and television stations. The government donated time on state-owned television stations for candidates' advertising and speeches so they could cut down on risky personal appearances.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Prisoners Shot, Killed By Guards at Stateville Correctional Center
DOC.TEXT: Two prisoners were shot and killed by prison guards quelling a gang fight Sunday night at a state prison, authorities said. Three other inmates were injured by either prisoners or guards during the 45-minute brawl involving about 10 inmates at Stateville Correctional Center, said Nic Howell, corrections spokesman. The prison was locked down to prevent further violence, he said. ``My understanding is the staff shot the inmates as they were attempting to do harm to other inmates,'' Howell said. DOC.HEAD: Assistant Principal Found De,ad in Burned Building
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with science teacher arrested, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A high school assistant principal was shot to death and left in a burning school building Sunday, and a science teacher was arrested, authorities said. Police identified the man arrested as Donald Givens. Other teachers who gathered outside Hickman County High School the day a baccalaureate ceremony was scheduled identified Givens as a science teacher. Givens was being held at the county jail in the death of Ron Wallace, 40, an assistant principal and athletic director at the school 40 miles southwest of Nashville. Wallace, whose body was found in a hallway outside a biology laboratory, had been shot twice, said police Officer Howard Choate. The fire appeared to be intentionally set, investigators said. ``The only thing we can say is that an arrest has been made, and that he will be charged with murder, and other charges may result,'' said Sheriff Frank Atkinson. Firefighters found Wallace's body about 9 a.m. CDT Sunday after a fire was reported at the school, Tennessee Bureau of Investigation Agent Bill Holt said. Hickman County School Superintendent Wayne Qualls said Wallace had gone to the school ``to straighten things up'' for a baccalaureate service scheduled for Sunday afternoon. The ceremony was cancelled, and school officials were considering whether to postpone graduation ceremonies set for Friday. Wallace's daughter was among those to graduate. Fire Chief Kenneth Thompson confirmed that the fire appeared to be arson. ``An accelerant was used. We don't know what it was yet,'' Thompson said. He said the fire was started in three different sections of the school. He said the damage was confined to the library, the English teacher's library and said the curtain on the auditorium stage had been set on fire. The fire didn't cause structural damage, Thompson said. Damage was estimated at $150,000.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch, Belgians Threaten to Block Signing of Bank Treaty
DOC.TEXT: The Netherlands and Belgium have threatened to contest the choice of a Frenchman as head of a new development bank for Eastern Europe and the choice of London as its headquarters. The 42 members of the $12 billion European Bank for Reconstruction and Development voted late Saturday to make Jacques Attali the institution's first president with London as its headquarters. Attali won over a Dutch rival. The treaty establishing the bank, which will finance Eastern Europe's transition to a market-oriented economy, is to be signed in Paris May 29. ''As far as we're concerned, there was no vote. It was simply an opinion poll,'' said Cees Maas, a senior Dutch Treasury official and head of the Dutch delegation. Dutch delegates said they intend to review their position prior to the treaty signing. There were 32 votes among the 42 founding members in favor of Attali, top aide to President Francois Mitterrand and credited with conceiving the idea of the bank. His Dutch rival for the chief executive's job, Onno Ruding, received eight. Two of the bank's members, the European Commission and the European Investment Bank, abstained. London received 23 votes as the choice for the bank's headquarters, while Amsterdam and Copenhagen gathered five each. Other cities in the running to host the institution were Berlin, Brussels, Dublin, Ljubljana, Madrid, Prague and Vienna. It was not immediately clear whether a decision by the Dutch and Belgians not to sign the treaty would prevent the bank from coming to life, but officials said privately that such a move certainly would delay the proceedings. The Dutch, backed by six other small Western European nations, have led a diplomatic offensive against the choices of Attali and London. They claim the selection was a ``precooked'' decision cobbled together by the seven leading industrialized countries in Washington earlier this month. ``The G-7 decision offended many people,'' commented one European official, noting that many of the smaller countries in the European Community felt they were being left out of the decision-making process. The 12 EC nations hold a controlling 51 percent interest in the bank. The United States is the bank's biggest single shareholder with a 10 percent stake. Eastern European countries will hold 13.5 percent. The G-7 agreement on Attali and London came after France and Britain settled a long-running dispute over their respective rankings inside the International Monetary Fund. That arrangement gives France equal ranking with Britain. Observers at the time said the deal was a trade-off, with Britain agreeing to the IMF reclassification if France would support London as the site of the development bank. The Dutch made a last-minute proposal on Friday to withdraw their support for Ruding, a former Dutch finance minister, if the other EC countries would agree to locate the bank in Amsterdam. Under the bank's statutes, two-thirds of the 42 founding members must ratify the treaty before the bank can start lending to countries in Eastern Europe. The ratification process must be completed by next spring.

DOC.HEAD: Marriot Says Its Considering Restaurant Sale but not Negotiating with Sizzler
DOC.TEXT: Marriott Corp. said it still is considering proposals to sell its family restaurant business but is not negotiating a sale with Sizzler Restaurants International Inc. Marriott said in a statement Saturday that numerous parties, including Sizzler, have expressed interest in the restaurants and that it is evaluating their proposals. But the company said it was not in negotiations with Sizzler, ``contrary to public statements made by Sizzler.'' ``No decision to negotiate with any single party has been made,'' the statement said. Marriott officials announced in December their intention to withdraw from the family restaurant business as part of a corporate restructuring aimed at focusing the company's assets. Based in Washington, D.C., Marriott currently operates over 400 restaurants including those under the names of Bob's Big Boy and Howard Johnson's.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Public Power Supply System Announces New Bond Refunding Sale
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Public Power Supply System has announced it will offer $600 million in refunding bonds for sale the week of June 4. The sale announced Friday would be the fourth in the effort by WPPSS and the federal Bonneville Power Administration to refinance about $2.8 billion in bonds sold a decade ago to finance construction of three nuclear power plants. The outstanding high-interest bonds carry interest rates upwards of 9 percent. About $1.6 billion in debt for WPPSS plants Nos. 1, 2 and 3 has been refinanced through issuance of new bonds carrying interest rates of from 6\ percent to 7} percent. WPPSS spokesman John Britton said Friday there will be at least one and possibly two more sales after June. He said all sales of refinancing bonds are to be completed this year. It has been estimated that the refinancing effort will save the Northwest region, which is paying for the WPPSS plants through BPA electricity rates, about $1 billion. Preston Michie, assistant general counsel with Bonneville, said it was hoped the bonds sold in June would be at about the range of interest rates received in the previous three sales. Previous sales were in October and December 1989 and in March of this year. Senior manager for the June sale is First Boston Corp. The supply system, headquartered in Richland, attempted to build five nuclear power plants in the 1970s. Of those, one plant, No. 2 at the Hanford nuclear reservation, is operating after starting up in late 1984. Two others, Nos. 1 and 3, are mothballed because of construction delays. WPPSS terminated the other two plants, Nos. 4 and 5, in 1982, and defaulted on $2.25 billion in bonds sold for their construction. Plants 1, 2 and 3 are being paid for through BPA rates. The Bonneville umbrella was never extended to plants Nos. 4 and 5.

DOC.HEAD: National Average Up 2.4 Cents a Gallon
DOC.TEXT: The average price of a gallon of gasoline at the nation's pumps rose 2.4 cents in the past two weeks, a survey showed. The price was 116.05 cents a gallon in the Lundberg Survey for the period ended May 18, up 2.4 cents from the average in the previous survey May 4, industry analyst Trilby Lundberg said Sunday. The average includes regular unleaded, premium unleaded and regular leaded gasoline and all taxes. Lundberg surveys 13,000 stations nationwide. Self-serve prices per gallon were: regular unleaded 104.47 cents; premium unleaded 121.65 cents; regular leaded 103.91 cents. Full-serve prices were: regular unleaded 130.98; premium unleaded 144.51; regular leaded 128.93.
